TEXT ONLY ENTRY: NOTICE TO PARTIES by District Cormac J. Carney. Effective October 9, 2018, Judge Cormac J. Carney will be located in the First Street U.S. Courthouse, Courtroom 7C, on the 7th floor, located at 350 W. 1st Street, Los Angeles, California 90012. All Court appearances shall be made in Courtroom 7C of the First Street U.S. Courthouse unless otherwise ordered by the Court. All required mandatory chambers copies shall be delivered and placed in the drop box located outside the Clerk's Office on the 4th floor of the First Street Courthouse. Judge Carney's Courtroom Deputy Clerk, Melissa H. Kunig, may be reached at (714) 338−2849. The location for filing civil and/or criminal documents in paper format exempted from electronic filing is at Edward R. Roybal Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse, 255 East Temple Street, Room 180, Los Angeles, California 90012. Documents under this exemption may also be filed in the Santa Ana or Riverside courthouses. Please refer to Judge Carney's Procedures & Schedules Page on the Court's website **UPDATED AS OF SEPTEMBER 24, 2018** for updated procedures regarding mandatory chambers copies. MINUTES OF Pre−Discovery Motion Telephone Conference held before Magistrate Judge Gail J. Standish regarding parties' February 28, 2019. The Court confers with the parties regarding their email of February 28, 2018, which sets forth various discovery disputes. As explained in more detail on the record, the Court orders counsel to meet and confer in an effort to narrow the issues presented in their e−mail. For those issues that remain, the Court sets the following briefing scheduled: petitioners' motion to compel is due by Wednesday, March 20, 2019; the opposition is due by Wednesday, March 27, 2018; the reply, if any, is due by Wednesday, April 3, 2019. Upon completion of the briefing, the Court will determine if a hearing is necessary, at which time counsel will be notified. Court Recorder: XTR. (ec) (Entered: 03/06/2019)

The Court has reviewed the parties joint e−mail seeking a pre−discovery motion telephonic conference related to Respondents assertion of the deliberative process privilege over a small subset of the documents produced. MINUTES OF Discovery Hearing held before Magistrate Judge Gail J. Standish regarding in camera documents reviewed by the Court. The narrow issue before the Court is whether certain redactions applied by Respondent to twenty−five documents, which the Court reviewed in camera, are proper. Specifically, Petitioners challenge whether, in asserting the deliberative process privilege as to these documents (in whole or in part), Respondents fulfilled their obligation to produce reasonably severable factual material. See F.T.C. v. Warner Commc'ns Inc., 742 F.2d 1156, 1161 (9th Cir. 1984). The documents at issue are primarily drafts of memoranda and internal analyses, and, in general, are documents to which the deliberative process privilege applies. (See order for details) Court Recorder: CS Roybal Courtroom 640. (efc) (Entered: 02/20/2020)

Text Only Entry: Order by Judge Standish. The Court has reviewed the parties joint e-mail seeking a pre-discovery motion telephonic conference related to Respondents assertion of the deliberative process privilege over a small subset of the documents produced. Given the impending discovery cutoff (January 29, 2020) and the parties agreement that in camera review is necessary, the Court dispenses with the pre-discovery motion teleconference requirement and sets the following briefing schedule: Respondents, who bear the burden of demonstrating that the privilege applies, will file their opening brief on or before Wednesday, January 8, 2020 and shall submit the disputed documents for in camera review at that time; Petitioners will file their response on or before Tuesday, January 14, 2020; Respondents reply, if any, is limited to five pages and is due on or before Thursday, January 16, 2020. THERE IS NO PDF DOCUMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THIS ENTRY. (vm) TEXT ONLY ENTRY (Entered: 01/03/2020)

MINUTES OF Discovery Hearing held before Magistrate Judge Gail J. Standish regarding in camera documents reviewed by the Court. The narrow issue before the Court is whether certain redactions applied by Respondent to twenty-five documents, which the Court reviewed in camera, are proper. Specifically, Petitioners challenge whether, in asserting the deliberative process privilege as to these documents (in whole or in part), Respondents fulfilled their obligation to produce reasonably severable factual material. See F.T.C. v. Warner Commc'ns Inc., 742 F.2d 1156, 1161 (9th Cir. 1984). The documents at issue are primarily drafts of memoranda and internal analyses, and, in general, are documents to which the deliberative process privilege applies. (See order for details) Court Recorder: CS Roybal Courtroom 640. (efc) (Entered: 02/20/2020)

case_data.name: Trinh v. Homan
case_data.plaintiff_description: Vietnamese immigrants who arrived in the U.S. before July 12, 1995 and have been or will be detained indefinitely pursuant to a final removal order.
special_collections: Trump Administration 1.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
On February 22, 2018, four Vietnamese refugees filed this habeas petition and class action lawsuit challenging U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for allegedly arbitrarily and unlawfully detaining them.

In January 2008, the United States and Vietnam entered an agreement governing the repatriation of Vietnamese nationals facing final orders of removal to Vietnam. One limit made part of the agreement was Vietnam's decision not to agree to repatriation of any national who had arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995. As a result, from 2008-2016, ICE maintained a policy of releasing Vietnamese nationals facing final orders of removal from ICE custody, given the impracticability of their deportation. However, in 2016, ICE reversed its policy, detaining Vietnamese nationals with final orders of removal indefinitely.

In the original complaint, the petitioners argued that this change in policy violated 8 U.S.C. § 1231, which prescribes a 90-day "removal period" in which to remove the detainee. Petitioners relied heavily upon the Supreme Court's 2001 opinion in Zadvydas v. Davis (533 U.S. 678), which held that Due Process precludes the United States from indefinitely detaining immigrants for whom it is not "reasonably foreseeable" that deportation can occur. In addition, petitioners argued that failing to provide an individualized assessment as to whether or not detention is even necessary, due to danger or flight risk, also violated 8 U.S.C. § 1231 and Due Process. Petitioners sought habeas, declaratory, and injunctive relief. Represented by Asian Americans Advancing Justice and the private law firms Reed Smith and Davis Adams, the habeas petition was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California (in Santa Ana).

The petition proposed three classes of Vietnamese refugees held after receiving final orders of removal: those detained for more than 90 days (90-day class), those detained for more than 180 days (180-day class), and those detained for longer than 180 days without an individualized hearing to assess whether detention is necessary based on danger or flight risk (prolonged detention class). All class members arrived in the U.S. before 1995 and had lived in the United States as legal permanent residents (LPR) ever since. Class members faced removal proceedings after becoming involved with the criminal justice system and losing their LPR status.

The case was initially assigned to Judge John A. Kronstadt. However, the plaintiffs in Chhoeun v. Marin, a case challenging ICE's detention of Cambodian refugees stripped of their legal permanent resident status due to criminal convictions, moved to relate this case to that one. On March 14, 2018, the motion was granted, and both cases were assigned to Judge Cormac J. Carney.

On April 25, 2018, the petitioners moved for a preliminary injunction to secure the release of the named defendants. However, soon thereafter, ICE released them from detention, mooting the motion. At this point, the government moved to dismiss the petition, arguing that its claims were now moot. Petitioners responded by filing an amended complaint, acknowledging that the original named petitioners had been released from ICE custody and adding new named petitioners who were in ICE detention at the time of filing.

In light of the amended complaint, Judge Cormac J. Carney dismissed the motion for a preliminary injunction on May 23, 2018, simply noting that the injunction was superseded by the new complaint and that the need for release no longer applied to the named petitioners in the original complaint. 2018 WL 3357577.

Judge Carney denied the government’s motion to dismiss on September 6, 2018. 333 F. Supp. 3d 984. The court held that the petitioners' claims were not moot because, although the named petitioners were released from detention, they could still be re-detained at any time and therefore still had a live habeas relief interest. The court also held that the petitioners had successfully pleaded claims upon which relief could be granted as to their assertions that their post-removal order detention was unlawful when removal was not likely in the foreseeable future and that detentions over six months without individualized bond hearings are unlawful.

On October 18, 2018, Judge Carney granted in part and denied in part class certification, granting certification to the 90-day and 180-day classes only as to the declaratory "issues of whether the Class has overcome the six month presumption of reasonableness and met its burden under Zadvydas [v. Davis (533 U.S. 678)]," declining to certify on the injunctive issue that would have limited the government's authority to detain immigrants past 180 days. The court furthermore certified the prolonged detention class, seeking injunctive relief to compel bond hearings for the detainees. 2018 WL 11184556.

After a year and a half of discovery, the petitioners moved for summary judgment on March 6, 2020, and the government cross-filed a month later on April 10. On June 11, 2020, the government's motion was granted in substantial part, settling all of the declaratory issues in favor of the government. Judge Carney's opinion repeatedly noted the validity of the petitioners' arguments, writing that "many class members may be able to show that there is 'good reason to believe' their removal is unlikely" but concluded that sweeping declarations as such would be inappropriate where individualized, fact-intensive review is the norm, noting that Zadvydas claims are usually made in individual habeas hearings.

Following this ruling, the petitioners moved to reconsider but then withdrew their motion. From there, the case went silent until May 5, 2021 when Judge Carney ordered the parties to show cause as to why the case should not be dismissed and closed. The petitioners have since responded to that order; however the contents of their response have been sealed for reasons unknown. It is unclear how the change from the Trump presidential administration to the Biden administration has affected this case. Under the Biden administration, on March 15, 2021, 33 Vietnamese nationals, including at least one who arrived in the United States before 1995, were deported to Vietnam. 

In the summer of 2021, the parties began negotiating a settlement. On July 19, 2021, Judge Cormac closed the case and stated that if a settlement was not reached within 90 days, the case would be reopened. 

On October 5, 2021, the case was dismissed. 

The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short:
Four refugees filed this class action suit in the U.S. Central District of California on behalf of Vietnamese immigrants facing orders of removal and indefinite detention by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), despite the fact that Vietnam has stated that it will not repatriate nationals who arrived in the U.S. before 1995. Judge Cormac J. Carney certified three classes of Vietnamese immigrants held in ICE detention in 2018 but subsequently dismissed their claims for declaratory relief in 2020 on the basis that it was inappropriate to grant sweeping declarations where individual review is required. 
In the summer of 2021, the parties began negotiating a settlement. On July 19, 2021, Judge Cormac closed the case and stated that if a settlement was not reached within 90 days, the case would be reopened. 
On October 5, 2021, the case was dismissed.

LEGAL BACKGROUND 
24
Detention 
25
22.  Following a final order of removal, ICE is directed by statute to detain 
26
an individual for 90 days in order to effectuate removal.  8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(2). This 
27
28

1
90-day period, also known as “the removal period,” generally commences as soon as 
2
a removal order becomes administratively final. § 1231(a)(1)(A), § 1231(a)(1)(B). 
3
23.  If ICE fails to remove an individual during the 90-day removal period, 
4
the  law  requires  ICE  to  release  the  individual  under  conditions  of  supervision, 
5
including periodic reporting. § 1231(a)(3) (“If the alien . . . is not removed within the 
6
removal  period,  the  alien,  pending  removal,  shall  be  subject  to 
7
supervision.”). Limited exceptions to this rule exist. Specifically, ICE “may” detain 
8
an individual beyond 90 days if the individual was ordered removed on criminal 
9
grounds or is determined to pose a danger or flight risk. § 1231(a)(6). However, 
10
ICE’s  authority  to  detain  an  individual  beyond  the  removal  period  under  such 
ware  11
Dela circumstances  is  not  boundless. Rather,  it  is  constrained  by  the  constitutional 
LLP  n the State of  1123 requirement that detention “bear a reasonable relationship to the purpose for which 
TH med i the  individual  [was]  committed.” Zadvydas  v.  Davis,  533  U.S.  678,  690  (2001) 
ED SMInership for 14 (citations omitted). Because the principal purpose of the post-final-order detention

A li
17
24.  The United States Supreme Court has accordingly construed Section 
18
1231(a)(6) as authorizing post-final order detention only for a “period reasonably 
19
necessary to secure removal,” a period that the Court determined to be presumptively 
20
six months. Id. at 699-701. After this six month period, if a detainee provides “good 
21
reason” to believe that his or her removal is not significantly likely in the reasonably 
22
foreseeable future, “the Government must respond with evidence sufficient to rebut 
23
that showing.” Id. at 701. If the government cannot do so, the individual must be 
24
released.  
25
25.  However, detainees are entitled to release even before six months of 
26
detention,  as  long  as  removal  is  not  reasonably  foreseeable.  See  8  C.F.R.  § 
27
241.13(b)(1)  (authorizing  release  after  90  days  where  removal  not  reasonably 
28

foreseeable).  Moreover,  as  the  period  of  post-final-order  detention  grows,  what 
2
counts as “reasonably foreseeable” must conversely shrink. Zadvydas at 701. 
3
26.  Even  where  detention  meets  the  Zadvydas  standard  for  reasonable 
4
foreseeability, detention violates the Due Process Clause unless it is “reasonably 
5
related” to the government’s purpose, which is to prevent danger or flight risk. See 
6
Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 700 (“[I]f removal is reasonably foreseeable, the habeas court 
7
should  consider  the  risk  of  the  alien’s  committing  further  crimes  as  a  factor 
8
potentially justifying confinement within that reasonable removal period”) (emphasis 
9
added);  id.  at  699  (purpose  of  detention  is  “assuring  the  alien’s  presence  at  the 
10
moment of removal”); id. at 690-91 (discussing twin justifications of detention as 
ware  11
Dela preventing  flight  and  protecting  the  community). Thus,  due  process  requires  a 
LLP  n the State of  1123 meaningful determination that Petitioners pose a danger or flight risk that warrant 
TH med i post-final-order detention, regardless of whether their removal can be effectuated

241.4(e)-(f). Among the factors to be considered in these custody reviews are “ties to

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 2 of 8   Page ID #:25
AGREEMENT
BETWEEN
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
AND
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM
ON
THE ACCEPTANCE OF THE RETURN OF VIETNAMESE CITIZENS
The Government of the United States of America (hereinafter called
"the U.S. Government") and the Government of the Socialist Republic of
Vietnam (hereinafter called "the Vietnamese Government"),
With a wish of developing friendly relations between the two countries,
and to establish procedures for competent authorities of both countries on the
prompt and orderly acceptance of Vietnamese citizens who have been ordered
removed by the U.S. Government,
In order to establish common procedures for the relevant authorities
based on the legal principles of each country and the international
responsibility to accept the return of repatriated citizens; and to follow
recognized principles of international law, to allow for a case-by-case
determination of repatriation, and to recognize the right of the receiving
country to determine nationality,
Have agreed to the following:
Article 1
General Provisions
1. The U.S. Government will carry out the repatriation of Vietnamese
citizens who violated U.S. law in accordance with U.S. and international law
and the provisions of this Agreement. The repatriation should take into
account the humanitarian aspect, family unity and circumstances of each
person in each individual case.
2. The Vietnamese Government may consider the return of its citizens
who violated U.S. law based on the consideration of legal procedures and the	
'/

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 3 of 8   Page ID #:26
status and circumstances of each individual case. The subject individuals and
the acceptance procedure will be based on the terms of this Agreement.
3. Repatriation will be carried out in an orderly and safe way, and with
respect for the individual human dignity of the person repatriated. The U.S.
Government will allow Vietnamese citizens who have been ordered removed
a reasonable time to arrange their personal affairs before returning them to
Vietnam.
4. Persons repatriated under this Agreement have the right to transfer
their legal money and personal property to Vietnam.
5. The U.S. Government will pay for the cost of returning to Vietnam
persons repatriated under this Agreement, as provided in Article 5 and Annex
1. The U.S. Government will also pay for the cost of returning to the United
States any person who was mistakenly repatriated, in accordance with Article
3 of this Agreement.
Article 2
Removable Persons and Conditions of Acceptance
1. The Vietnamese Government will accept the return of Vietnamese
citizens in accordance with Article 1 and item 2 of Article 2 of this
Agreement, if upon investigation the individual meets the following
requirements:
(a) The individual is a citizen of Vietnam and is not a citizen of the
United States or of any other country;
(b) The individual previously resided in Vietnam and has no current
residence in a third country;
(c) The individual has violated U.S. laws and has been ordered by
competent authority removed from the United States; and
(d) If the individual has been convicted of a criminal offense (including
immigration violation), the person will have completed any imprisonment
before removal, and any reduction in sentence will have been ordered by
competent authority.
2. Vietnamese citizens are not subject to return to Vietnam under this
Agreement if they arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995, the date
on which diplomatic relations were re-established between the U.S.
A	 1111

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 4 of 8   Page ID #:27
Government and the Vietnamese Government. The U.S. Government and the
Vietnamese Government maintain their respective legal positions relative to
Vietnamese citizens who departed Vietnam for the United States prior to that
date.
3. In the case of a citizen of Vietnam who immigrated to the United
States from a third country where that person had a permanent residence and
who has been ordered removed from the United States, the U.S. Government
will seek to return that person to the third country or consider allowing that
person to stay in the United States, before requesting removal to Vietnam.
4. In any case where the Vietnamese Government obtains information
relevant to the repatriation of an individual that was not previously considered
by the U.S. Government, the Vietnamese Government may request a
humanitarian reconsideration based on the specific circumstances of the
repatriated person in accordance with United States law.
Article 3
Return of Persons Repatriated in Error
Upon notice by the Vietnamese Government that a person returned to
Vietnam by the U.S. Government does not meet all criteria mentioned in
Article 2 of this Agreement, the U.S. Government should promptly receive
the return of that person to the United States without any special procedure.
Article 4
Acceptance Procedures
1. When the U.S. Government believes that a removable person is a
citizen of Vietnam and meets all criteria within Article 2 of this Agreement,
the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, on behalf of the U.S.
Government, will request appropriate travel documents from the Vietnamese
Government and will forward the appropriate files to that Government. Such
files will include three sets of documents, the original and two copies. The
original and one copy shall be forwarded to the Vietnamese Ministry of
Public Security (Immigration Department) by the U.S. Embassy in Vietnam,
and the other copy will be sent to the Vietnamese Ministry of Foreign Affairs
(Consular Department).
Each file will contain a diplomatic note which requests that the
Vietnamese Government accept the returnee, the name of the person the U.S.
Government believes should be repatriated to Vietnam, the appropriate forms
completed by such person (an example of which is provided in Annex 2 of

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 5 of 8   Page ID #:28
this Agreement), a copy of the order of removal, and other documents
regarding the person's biography, citizenship, criminal history, sentence
imposed, and decision of amnesty or reduction of criminal sentence. The
order of removal will be translated into Vietnamese on the standard form, and
the criminal history will include a National Crime Information Center (NCIC)
record in English accompanied by a code key translated into Vietnamese. All
documents and translations will be certified by the competent U.S. authorities.
2. Upon request by the Vietnamese Government, the U.S. Government
will arrange and facilitate the interview of persons who fall within Article
2(1) of this Agreement by Vietnamese immigration officials to determine
information regarding the Vietnamese citizenship, biographical data, and last
place of residence of such persons. The U.S. Department of Homeland
Security will arrange a venue for those interviews. The U.S. Government also
will facilitate interviews by U.S.-based consular officers of the Vietnamese
Government of deportable persons whom the U.S. believes to be Vietnamese
citizens.
3. The Vietnamese Government will provide a prompt response to the
U.S. Government on cases referred under this Article after the Vietnamese
verification is made. If it is determined that a person whose name and file has
been provided to the Vietnamese Government in accordance with this Article
meets the requirements of Article 2, the Ministry of Public Security of the
Vietnamese Government will issue a travel document authorizing that
person's return to Vietnam, and will provide written notification to the U.S.
Embassy in Vietnam.
4. When the Vietnamese Government has issued a travel document
under this Agreement, the U.S. Government will provide at least fifteen (15)
days notice of the flight and travel arrangements by which the person will be
returned to Vietnam. The U.S. Embassy in Vietnam will inform the Ministry
of Public Security (Immigration Department) and the Ministry of Foreign
Affairs (Consular Department) of the date and number of the flight, the time
of arrival, the port of entry (Noi Bai Airport in Hanoi or Tan Son Nhat Airport
in Ho Chi Minh City), and the details regarding any U.S. officers escorting
the person to be returned (such as names, dates of birth, passport numbers,
estimated times of stay in Vietnam, etc), and allow the Vietnamese side to
confirm receipt of the returnees.
When a person under medical treatment is returned to Vietnam under
this Agreement, the escorting U.S. officers will provide a copy of the person's
health record to the receiving Vietnamese officials at the port of entry. The

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 6 of 8   Page ID #:29
escorting and receiving officers will sign a joint report verifying the person's
repatriation.
Article 5
Expenses
1. The U.S. Government will pay for the cost of transporting
Vietnamese citizens to Vietnam under this Agreement.
2. The U.S. Government will pay for the costs of receiving repatriated
persons including: verifying fee, the receipt at the airport and transportation of
the persons from airport to the place of residences in accordance with the
enclosed Annex 1.
3. The U.S. Government will pay for the cost of arranging interviews
by relevant Vietnamese officials of persons whom the U.S. Government
believes to be Vietnamese citizens and subject to repatriation under this
Agreement.
4. The U.S. Government will pay for the cost of returning to the United
States persons who were repatriated in error, as provided in Article 3 of this
Agreement.
Article 6
Entry into Force and Duration
1.This Agreement will enter into force sixty (60) days from the date of
signature by both Governments.
2. Upon entry into force, this Agreement will be valid for five years.
The Agreement will be extended automatically for terms of three years
thereafter unless written notice not to extend is given by one Government to
the other at least six months prior to the expiration date of the Agreement.
Article 7
Amendment and Supplementation
This Agreement may be amended or supplemented by written
agreement of the Vietnamese Government and the U.S. Government through
appropriate diplomatic channels.

Case 8:18-cv-00316   Document 1-1   Filed 02/22/18   Page 7 of 8   Page ID #:30
Article 8
Resolution of Disputes
Any disputes regarding the interpretation and implementation of this
Agreement will be resolved through appropriate diplomatic channels.
Article 9
Suspension or Termination
This Agreement may be suspended or terminated by either
Government. Such suspension or termination of this Agreement will come
into effect after thirty days (30) from the date one Government receives the
written notification from the other Government of its intention to suspend or
terminate.
Done at Hanoi, on 22 January 2008 in duplicate in the English and
Vietnamese languages, both texts being equally authentic.
	
FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF
	
THE UNITED STATES OF THE SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF
	
AMERICA VIETNAM

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 1 of 18   Page ID #:839

NGUYEN, NGOC HOANG, DAI DIEP,

)   
behalf of themselves and those similarly 
14 )

)  MOTION TO DISMISS AND HABEAS 
16     Petitioners,  )  RETURN 
) 
17   v.  )

18 ) 
THOMAS D. HOMAN, KIRSTJEN M. 
) 
19 NIELSEN, JEFFERSON B. SESSIONS  )

HUTCHENS, and JOHN DOE,

  )   
23
24  
25 I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
26
  The seven named Petitioners bring this Habeas Corpus Petition and Class Action 
27
Complaint on behalf of themselves and a putative class of Vietnamese citizens who 
28
-1- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 2 of 18   Page ID #:840
 
immigrated to the United States before 1995.  (Dkt. 27 [First Amended Habeas Corpus 
1
Petition and Class Action Complaint, hereinafter “FAC”] ¶¶ 1–4.)  Petitioners allege that 
2
in 2017, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”) began subjecting these 
3
“pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants” to prolonged, post-removal order detention despite 
4
the purportedly remote possibility of their removal to Vietnam.  (Id. ¶ 4.)  
5
  
6
Petitioners bring two causes of action for habeas relief, declaratory relief, and 
7
injunctive relief.  (Id. ¶ 76.)  In Count One, Petitioners assert that their post-removal 
8
order detention violates federal immigration law, 8 U.S.C. § 1231, and constitutional due 
9
process where removal is not likely to occur in the foreseeable future.  (Id. ¶¶ 64–70.)  In 
10
Count Two, Petitioners assert that even where removal is reasonably foreseeable, their 
11
prolonged detention violates section 1231 and constitutional due process when it is 
12
“without any individualized determination that they pose a danger or flight risk.”  (Id. ¶¶ 
13
72–75.)   
14
 
15
Petitioners bring these causes of action on behalf of themselves and three putative 
16
classes: (1) all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by 
17
ICE for more than 90 days after receiving removal orders (“90-Day Class”), (2) all pre-
18
1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by ICE for more than 
19
180 days after receiving removal orders (“180-Day Class”), and (3) all pre-1995 
20
Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by ICE for more than 180 
21
days without a bond hearing (“Prolonged Detention Class”).  (Id. ¶ 59.)  
22
 
23
  Before the Court is Defendants’ hybrid motion to dismiss and habeas return. (Dkt. 
24
56 [hereinafter “Mot.”].)  For the following reasons, the motion is DENIED.1 
25
26
                                                           
27
1  Having read and considered the papers presented by the parties, the Court finds this matter appropriate 
28 for disposition without a hearing.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 78; Local Rule 7-15.  Accordingly, the hearing set 
for September 10, 2018, at 1:30 p.m. is hereby vacated and off calendar. 
-2- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 3 of 18   Page ID #:841
 
II.  BACKGROUND 
1
 
2
  Petitioners are citizens of Vietnam who immigrated to the United States before 
3
July 12, 1995.  (FAC ¶ 1.)  Petitioners became lawful permanent residents years ago but, 
4
based on criminal convictions, lost their green cards and were ordered removed.  (Id. ¶ 2.)  
5
Petitioners allege that until recently, ICE had a longstanding practice of detaining pre-
6
1995 Vietnamese immigrants for no longer than 90 days.  (Id. ¶ 3.)  This practice was 
7
purportedly implemented because a 2008 diplomatic agreement between the United 
8
States and Vietnam provides that Vietnamese citizens who arrived to the United States 
9
before July 12, 1995 are not subject to return to Vietnam.  (Id. ¶¶ 2, 36; Ex. A, Art. 2, ¶ 
10
2.)  The parties seemingly do not dispute that the 2008 agreement is still in effect.2 
11
 
12
  Petitioners allege that in 2017, ICE departed from this longstanding practice and 
13
began subjecting pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants to prolonged periods of detention.  
14
(Id. ¶ 4.)  ICE also purportedly began re-detaining, without notice, pre-1995 Vietnamese 
15
immigrants who had previously been released from detention and were living on orders 
16
of supervision.  (Id.)  On February 22, 2018, four of the named Petitioners filed this 
17
action challenging their detention.  (Dkt. 1.)  On April 30, 2018, the Government moved 
18
to dismiss the case, arguing it was moot because the four named Petitioners had since 
19
been released from custody.  (Dkt. 24.)  On May 11, 2018, Petitioners filed the operative 
20
First Amended Habeas Corpus Petition and Class Action Complaint, adding three new 
21
Petitioners who were, at the time, in immigration detention.  (FAC.)  All seven named 
22
Petitioners, described below, have now been released from custody. 
23
 
24
25                                                            
2 The agreement can be accessed on the U.S. Department of State’s website at 
26
https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/108921.pdf.  The agreement states it will be valid for five 
years and extended automatically for successive three-year terms thereafter, unless written notice not to 
27
extend is given by either country.  (TAC Ex. A, Art. 6.)  Petitioners allege and Defendants do not contest 
28 that the agreement has not been terminated or modified by either country.  (TAC ¶ 35; see generally 
Mot.)  
-3- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 4 of 18   Page ID #:842
 
  Hoang Trinh, the first named Petitioner, is a resident of Orange County, California, 
1
who legally entered the United States as a four-year-old refugee in 1980.  (Id. ¶ 11.)  He 
2
became a lawful permanent resident, married, and now has two children ages thirteen and 
3
eighteen.  (Id.)  Hoang’s wife, two children, parents, and six sisters are all U.S. citizens.  
4
(Id.)  In early 2015, Hoang was arrested on a drug charge, for which he served one year 
5
in prison.  (Id.)  Hoang was later incarcerated for alleged possession of a marijuana plant 
6
before being transferred to ICE custody in June 2017.  (Id.)  He was ordered removed on 
7
July 27, 2017.  (Id.)  He remained in immigration detention until April 16, 2018, when he 
8
was released on an order of supervision.  (Id.)  He did not receive a bond hearing.  (Id.)   
9
 
10
  Petitioner Vu Ha is a resident of Orange County, California, who legally entered 
11
the United States as a ten-year-old refugee in 1990 and became a lawful permanent 
12
resident shortly thereafter.  (Id. ¶ 12.)  His parents, sister, and daughter are U.S. citizens.  
13
(Id.)  He was arrested three times as a young adult between 2000 and 2005, once being 
14
for robbery.  (Id.)  In 2017, he was arrested and detained for failure to pay a citation for 
15
driving without a license.  (Id.)  He was transported from county jail to ICE custody in 
16
May 2017 and was ordered removed on September 19, 2017.  (Id.)  He remained in 
17
immigration detention until April 13, 2018, when he was released on an order of 
18
supervision.  (Id.)  He did not receive a bond hearing.  (Id.)   
19
 
20
  Petitioner Long Nguyen is a resident of Charleston, South Carolina, who legally 
21
entered the United States as an eleven-year-old refugee in 1987 and became a lawful 
22
permanent resident the following year.  (Id. ¶ 13.)  Nguyen’s wife and five children are 
23
all U.S. citizens, and his parents are lawful permanent residents.  (Id.)  Nguyen and his 
24
wife have worked together for many years at a nail salon his wife manages.  (Id.)  In 
25
2006, he was convicted of a nonviolent felony drug offense.  (Id.)  In 2010 or 2011, he 
26
was detained after traveling abroad and ordered removed on April 18, 2012.  (Id.)  He 
27
was released on an order of supervision after Vietnam refused to accept his deportation.  
28
-4- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 5 of 18   Page ID #:843
 
(Id.)  Although he reliably reported to ICE for years under his order of supervision, he 
1
was pulled over on his way to work and detained from October 19, 2017 to March 23, 
2
2018, when he was again released on an order of supervision.  (Id.)   
3
 
4
  Petitioner Ngoc Hoang is a resident of Gwinnett County, Georgia, who legally 
5
entered the United States in 1990.  (Id. ¶ 14.)  Hoang was married to a U.S. citizen with 
6
whom he has four children, all under the age of eighteen.  (Id.)  Hoang works as a nail 
7
salon technician.  (Id.)  In 1994, he pled guilty to check fraud and in 2010, he was placed 
8
on probation for simple assault and simple battery.  (Id.)  He was ordered removed on 
9
December 12, 2012 and released on an order of supervision approximately two months 
10
later.  (Id.)  Over the next five years, Hoang complied with the requirements of that order.  
11
(Id.)  But on November 6, 2017, he was unexpectedly re-arrested by ICE officers at his 
12
home.  (Id.)  He was detained until April 23, 2018, when he was released on an order of 
13
supervision.  (Id.)   
14
 
15
  Petitioner Sieu Nguyen is a resident of Sacramento, California, who escaped 
16
Vietnam when he was three years old.  (Id. ¶ 15.)  Sieu and his family were accepted as 
17
refugees in September 1989, and he became a lawful permanent resident shortly 
18
thereafter.  (Id.)  His parents and seven siblings are all U.S. citizens.  (Id.)  Sieu was 
19
convicted of robbery in 2007 and burglary and receipt of stolen property in 2010.  (Id.)  
20
After serving time in prison, he was transferred to a detention facility.  (Id.)  He was 
21
ordered removed on December 19, 2017, (id.), and has since been released from custody.  
22
  
23
  Petitioner Dai Diep is a resident of Santa Ana, California, who legally entered the 
24
United States as a refugee in 1995 and became a lawful permanent resident the following 
25
year.  (Id. ¶ 16.)  He arrived with his mother, stepfather, and two half-siblings, all of 
26
whom are now U.S. citizens.  (Id.)  In November 2015, he pled guilty to second-degree 
27
robbery, second-degree burglary, and vandalism, for which he was sentenced to two 
28
-5- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 6 of 18   Page ID #:844
 
years of imprisonment.  (Id.)  In April 2017, he was released on parole from state prison 
1
and transferred to ICE custody.  (Id.)  He was ordered removed on October 26, 2017, 
2
(id.), and has since been released from custody. 
3
 
4
  Petitioner Bao Duong is a resident of San Diego, California, who legally entered 
5
the United States as a refugee in 1980 and became a lawful permanent resident the same 
6
year.  (Id. ¶ 17.)  His parents are lawful permanent residents and his three sisters are U.S. 
7
citizens.  (Id.)  In 2013, Duong was convicted of robbery and imprisoned for three years.  
8
(Id.)  He was released on parole in June 2016 and arrested for alleged possession of 
9
marijuana in September 2017.  (Id.)  He was transferred to ICE custody and ordered 
10
removed from the United States on November 14, 2017.  (Id.)  He has since been released 
11
from custody. 
12
 
13
  Petitioners allege that ICE’s abrupt change in practices with respect to the named 
14
Petitioners and similarly situated individuals is unlawful because there is no evidence that 
15
Vietnam will now accept the return of pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants.  (Id. ¶ 54.)  
16
Defendants argue that ICE’s change in practices was based on a “new understanding” 
17
between the United States and Vietnam regarding the removal of pre-1995 immigrants.  
18
(Mot. at 14.)  Defendants assert that pursuant to that understanding, ICE has removed 
19
eleven pre-1995 individuals to Vietnam since July 2017.  (Dkt. 37-1 [Declaration of 
20
Michael Bernacke, hereinafter “Bernacke Decl.”] ¶ 6; Dkt. 56-1 [Second Declaration of 
21
Michael Bernacke, hereinafter “Bernacke Decl. II”] ¶ 6.) 
22
 
23
  On July 2, 2018, Defendants filed an ex parte application to sever Petitioners’ 
24
habeas and civil rights claims.  (Dkt. 53.)  The Court denied the application because both 
25
of Petitioners’ claims “seek habeas relief, along with injunctive and declaratory relief.”  
26
(Dkt. 54 at 4.)  On July 20, 2018, Defendants filed the instant hybrid motion to dismiss 
27
and habeas return.  (Dkt. 56.)  On August 28, 2018, Petitioners filed a motion for 
28
-6- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 7 of 18   Page ID #:845
 
certification of its three putative classes under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2).  
1
(Dkt. 65.)   
2
 
3
III.  DISCUSSION 
4
 
5
  Defendants move to dismiss Petitioners’ claims as moot under Federal Rule of 
6
Civil Procedure 12(b)(1) because the seven named Petitioners have been released from 
7
custody.  In the alternative, Defendants move to deny habeas relief on the merits and 
8
dismiss the non-habeas claims for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6).   
9
Defendants also argue that Petitioners’ claims with respect to the putative 90-Day Class 
10
members are premature.  The Court considers each argument in turn. 
11
 
12
A.  Mootness   
13
 
14
  Defendants first move to dismiss both of Petitioners’ claims as moot.  (Mot. at 10.)  
15
Defendants argue that this action does not involve a live case or controversy because the 
16
seven named Petitioners have been released from detention, and no exception to 
17
mootness applies.  (Id. at 11.)  Petitioners contend that their action continues to present a 
18
live case or controversy despite Petitioners’ release.  (Opp. at 7–10.)  Petitioners also 
19
argue that even if their habeas claims are moot, the “inherently transitory” exception to 
20
mootness applies.  The inherently transitory exception applies where a class 
21
representative’s claims will likely expire before the court can certify a class and other 
22
similarly situated individuals will continue to suffer the same injury.  Pitts v. Terrible 
23
Herbst, Inc., 653 F.3d 1081, 1090 (9th Cir. 2011).  When a claim is inherently transitory, 
24
certification of the class “relat[es] back” to the time the complaint was filed to “preserve 
25
the merits of the case for judicial resolution.”  County of Riverside v. McLaughlin, 500 
26
U.S. 44, 52 (1991).  Because the Court finds that Petitioners’ claims are not moot, it need 
27
not address whether the inherently transitory exception to mootness applies.  
28
-7- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 8 of 18   Page ID #:846
 
  Mootness is properly raised in a Rule 12(b)(1) motion to dismiss.  White v. Lee, 
1
227 F.3d 1214, 1242 (9th Cir. 2000).  For a court to have Article III standing to hear a 
2
case, there must be an actual case or controversy.  U.S. Const. art. III, § 2, cl. 1.  The 
3
plaintiff must allege a concrete injury in fact that is fairly traceable to the defendant’s 
4
unlawful conduct and that is likely redressable by a favorable decision.  Lujan v. 
5
Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992).  If circumstances arise such that issues 
6
are no longer “live” or the parties no longer hold a “legally cognizable interest” in the 
7
action, the court must dismiss the action as moot.  Powell v. McCormack, 395 U.S. 486, 
8
496 (1969).  However, “a case is not moot if any effective relief may be granted,” and the 
9
party asserting mootness “bears a heavy burden.”  Karuk Tribe of Calif. v. U.S. Forest 
10
Serv., 681 F.3d 1006, 1017 (9th Cir. 2012).   
11
 
12
  Petitioners’ claims continue to present a live controversy despite the named 
13
Petitioners’ release from detention.  A habeas petition continues to present a live 
14
controversy after a petitioner’s release if there is “some remaining collateral consequence 
15
that may be redressed by success on that petition.”  Abdala v. Immigration & 
16
Naturalization Serv., 488 F.3d 1061, 1064 (9th Cir. 2007), cert. denied (internal citations 
17
and quotations omitted).  Because Plaintiffs may be re-detained at any time, they retain a 
18
live interest in habeas relief.  See Rodriguez v. Hayes, 591 F.3d 1105, 1117 (9th Cir. 
19
2009) (ICE’s release of petitioner did not moot habeas petition where there was “no 
20
meaningful substantive limit” on ICE’s ability to re-detain him); Clark v. Martinez, 543 
21
U.S. 371, 376 n.3 (2005) (petitioner’s unlawful detention claim continued to involve a 
22
“live case or controversy” because his release could be revoked in ICE’s discretion).   
23
 
24
Defendants rely on Abdala v. INS for the assertion that “a habeas petition does not 
25
continue to present a live controversy once the petitioner is released from custody.”  
26
(Mot. 11.)  However, Defendants overstate Abdala’s holding.  In Abdala, the Ninth 
27
Circuit held that the habeas petition challenging only the length of detention became 
28
-8- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 9 of 18   Page ID #:847
 
moot when the petitioner was deported, not simply released in ICE’s discretion, because 
1
the court could no longer provide any relief.  Id. at 1065.  The Ninth Circuit in Abdala 
2
stated, however, that even “[d]eportation from the United States after filing a habeas 
3
petition does not necessarily moot a petitioner’s claim.”  Id. at 1063.  In the other cases 
4
that Defendants cite, the petitioners had been deported or had already received the relief 
5
they sought.  See Qalinle v. Donahue, 2016 WL 674939, at *2 (D. Ariz. Jan. 29, 2016) 
6
(characterizing petitioner’s claim as moot because the relief he requested, an order of 
7
supervision, could not be granted where petitioner was already released from custody); 
8
Martinez-Reyes v. Burns, 2011 WL 1375293, at *2 (C.D. Cal. Mar. 18, 2011) (holding 
9
that because petitioner’s removal to Mexico meant he was released from ICE custody, he 
10
“received the only relief [the] Court might provide him” under his habeas petition).  Here, 
11
by contrast, Petitioners do not seek release from detention alone.  Petitioners also seek 
12
declaratory relief that their removal to Vietnam is not reasonably foreseeable and that 
13
they are entitled to individualized bond hearings.  The Court can still provide Petitioners 
14
relief.  Defendants have failed to meet their “heavy burden” of showing Petitioners’ 
15
claims are moot.  See Karuk Tribe of Calif., 681 F.3d at 1017.  
16
 
17
B.  Failure to State a Claim  
18
 
19
Defendants next move to dismiss Petitioners’ claims for failure to state a claim 
20
under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).  (Mot. at 13.)3  A motion to dismiss 
21
under Rule 12(b)(6) tests the legal sufficiency of the claims asserted in the complaint.  
22
The issue on a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim is not whether the claimant 
23
24
                                                           
25 3 Defendants filed a hybrid motion to dismiss and habeas return, seeking dismissal of the non-habeas 
claims for failure to state a claim and denial of habeas relief on the merits.  (Mot. at 1.)  To the extent 
26
that Defendants ask the Court to sever Petitioners’ claims into their habeas and non-habeas components, 
the Court has already declined to do so.  (See Dkt. 54 [order denying Defendants’ ex parte application].)  
27
And for the Court to reach the merits of the habeas claims, an evidentiary hearing is required because 
28 there is a factual dispute regarding whether Petitioners face a significant likelihood of removal in the 
foreseeable future.  Owino v. Napolitano, 575 F.3d 952, 956 (9th Cir. 2009). 
-9- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 10 of 18   Page ID #:848
 
will ultimately prevail, but whether the claimant is entitled to offer evidence to support 
1
the claims asserted.  Gilligan v. Jamco Dev. Corp., 108 F.3d 246, 249 (9th Cir. 1997).  
2
Rule 12(b)(6) is read in conjunction with Rule 8(a), which requires only a short and plain 
3
statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 
4
8(a)(2).  When evaluating a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the district court must accept all 
5
material allegations in the complaint as true and construe them in the light most favorable 
6
to the non-moving party.  Moyo v. Gomez, 32 F.3d 1382, 1384 (9th Cir. 1994).  The 
7
district court may also consider additional facts in materials that the district court may 
8
take judicial notice, Barron v. Reich, 13 F.3d 1370, 1377 (9th Cir. 1994), as well as 
9
“documents whose contents are alleged in a complaint and whose authenticity no party 
10
questions, but which are not physically attached to the pleading,” Branch v. Tunnell, 14 
11
F.3d 449, 454 (9th Cir. 1994), overruled in part on other grounds by Galbraith v. Cnty. of 
12
Santa Clara, 307 F.3d 1119 (9th Cir. 2002).   
13
14
 
15 However, “the tenet that a court must accept as true all of the allegations contained 
16 in a complaint is inapplicable to legal conclusions.”  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 
17 (2009); see also Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007) (stating that while 
18 a complaint attacked by a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss does not need detailed factual 
19 allegations, courts “are not bound to accept as true a legal conclusion couched as a factual 
20 allegation” (citations and quotations omitted)).  Dismissal of a complaint for failure to 
21 state a claim is not proper where a plaintiff has alleged “enough facts to state a claim to 
22 relief that is plausible on its face.”  Twombly, 550 U.S. at 570.   
23
 
24 1.  Count One: Likelihood of Removal  
25  
26 In Count One, Petitioners assert that their post-removal order detention violates 
27 federal immigration law and constitutional due process where their removal is not likely 
28 to occur in the reasonably foreseeable future.  (FAC ¶¶ 64–70.)   Petitioners assert Count 
-10- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 11 of 18   Page ID #:849
 
One on behalf of all three putative classes.  Defendants argue that Count One does not 
1
state a claim because Petitioners have failed to establish that pre-1995 Vietnamese 
2
immigrants are not likely to be removed in the foreseeable future.  (Mot. at 13–15.)  
3
Defendants also argue that Count One as to the 90-Day Class is unripe.  (Id. at 16–18). 
4
 
5
  Petitioners’ post-removal order detention is governed by federal immigration law, 
6
8 U.S.C. § 1231.  Section 1231 provides that after an alien is ordered removed, the 
7
Government “shall remove the alien from the United States within a period of 90 days.”  
8
Id. § 1231(a)(1)(A).  During the 90-day removal period, the Government “shall detain the 
9
alien.”  Id. § 1231(a)(2).  Once the 90-day removal period ends, the Government may 
10
continue to detain certain aliens, such as Petitioners, whose criminal convictions render 
11
them removable.  Id. § 1231(a)(6).  Section 1231(a)(6), however, does not authorize the 
12
Government to detain an alien indefinitely.  Zadvydas v. Davis, 533 U.S. 678, 688–702 
13
(2001).  Rather, the statute, “read in light of the Constitution’s demands, limits an alien’s 
14
post-removal-period detention to a period reasonably necessary to bring about the alien’s 
15
removal.”  Id. at 689.  In Zadvydas, the Supreme Court held that six months is a 
16
“presumptively” reasonable period of detention.  Id. at 701.  If after six months, the 
17
noncitizen provides “good reason to believe that there is no significant likelihood of 
18
removal in the reasonably foreseeable future,” the Government must provide sufficient 
19
evidence to rebut the noncitizen’s showing of indefinite detention.  Id.  
20
 
21
  Petitioners argue that their removal is unlikely to occur in the reasonably 
22
foreseeable future because the 2008 United States-Vietnam diplomatic agreement 
23
“expressly excludes pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants from repatriation.”  (FAC ¶ 67.)   
24
That agreement provides that “Vietnamese citizens are not subject to return to Vietnam 
25
under this agreement if they arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995.”  (Id. Ex. 
26
A, Art. 2, ¶ 2.)  Petitioners assert that ICE has had a longstanding practice of releasing 
27
pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants under removal orders on the basis of this agreement.  
28
-11- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 12 of 18   Page ID #:850
 
(FAC ¶ 3.)  Because these immigrants are “not subject to return to Vietnam,” Petitioners 
1
contend that ICE has typically released them on orders of supervision.  (Id.)  Although 
2
ICE has since departed from that practice and has begun subjecting pre-1995 Vietnamese 
3
immigrants to longer post-removal order detention, (id. ¶ 4), Petitioners argue that 
4
removal is still not reasonably foreseeable for two reasons.  First, Petitioners argue that 
5
the 2008 repatriation agreement is still in effect.  Second, Petitioners argue that 
6
Vietnam’s past practice of refusing these immigrants shows it will continue to refuse 
7
repatriation of the “hundreds of pre-1995 Vietnamese [immigrants] whom ICE is 
8
currently detaining or will likely detain under its current detention campaign.”  (Id. ¶¶ 51, 
9
54.)     
10
 
11
  Petitioners have alleged sufficient facts to state a claim for indefinite detention that 
12
is “plausible on its face.”  See Twombly, 550 U.S. at 570.  Under Zadvydas, a noncitizen’s 
13
detention under section 1231(a)(6) is limited to a “period reasonably necessary to bring 
14
about that alien’s removal.”  533 U.S. at 689.  Here, Petitioners allege that their detention 
15
is unlawful because there is no likelihood of removal in the reasonably foreseeable future.  
16
In support of this allegation, Petitioners allege that due to the 2008 repatriation agreement 
17
still in effect, Vietnam has not accepted the great majority of pre-1995 immigrants.  (FAC 
18
¶¶ 51, 54.)  According to ICE’s estimates, 6,200 of the 7,700 Vietnamese immigrants 
19
subject to final orders of removal in 2008 immigrated to the United States before 1995.  
20
(Id. ¶ 44.)  Although Petitioners acknowledge that a small number of pre-1995 
21
Vietnamese immigrants have since been removed, that number pales in comparison to the 
22
estimated 6,200 pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who are either in detention or face the 
23
risk of future detention.  (See id. ¶¶ 44, 52.)  Named Petitioners Vu Ha and Hoang Trinh, 
24
for instance, were both held in immigration detention for approximately 300 days, far 
25
past the presumptively reasonable six-month period in Zadvydas.  (See id. ¶¶ 11, 12.)   
26
 
27
// 
28
-12- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 13 of 18   Page ID #:851
 
  Defendants nevertheless argue that Plaintiffs have failed to state a claim under 
1
Count One because recent developments in United States-Vietnam relations indicate that 
2
removal to Vietnam is no longer unlikely in the foreseeable future.  Defendants assert 
3
that the 2008 United States-Vietnam diplomatic agreement provides that citizens are not 
4
subject to return to Vietnam under the terms of that agreement only.  (Mot. at 14 [citing 
5
FAC Ex. A, Art. 2, ¶ 2].)  The United States may however, “under agreements or 
6
understandings other than the 2008 amendment,” still remove pre-1995 Vietnamese 
7
immigrants.  (Mot. at 14.)   Defendants assert that the United States and Vietnam reached 
8
one such understanding in mid-2017, pursuant to which ICE has removed eleven pre-
9
1995 Vietnamese immigrants since July 2017.  (Mot. at 14 [citing Bernacke Decl. ¶ 6; 
10
Bernacke Decl. II ¶ 6].)  For these assertions, Defendants rely on sworn affidavits by an 
11
ICE official. (See Bernacke Decl. ¶ 1.) 
12
  
13
  On a motion to dismiss under Federal Rule 12(b)(6), however, the Court “may not 
14
consider any material beyond the pleadings.”  Friedman v. AARP, Inc., 855 F.4d 1047, 
15
1051 (9th Cir. 2017).  Defendants argue that the pleadings standards under Rule 12 are 
16
“inconsistent with the standards and procedures” that the Supreme Court outlined in 
17
Zadvydas.  (Dkt. 62 [Reply] at 5.)  Defendants claim that on a motion to dismiss a 
18
Zadvydas claim, the Court should not accept the petitioner’s allegations as true and must 
19
consider the defendant’s declarations and other evidence beyond the pleadings.  (Id. at 6.)  
20
The Court declines to adopt Defendants’ approach here.  The Supreme Court in Zadvydas 
21
established a burden-shifting framework by which Defendants have an opportunity to 
22
rebut Petitioners’ showing.  Defendants fail to cite any binding authority that interprets 
23
Zadvydas as requiring this Court to eschew well-established pleading standards.  Given 
24
ICE’s allegedly longstanding practice of not removing pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants 
25
and the 2008 diplomatic agreement, Petitioners have stated a plausible claim for relief 
26
under Count One. 
27
 
28
-13- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 14 of 18   Page ID #:852
 
  Defendants alternatively argue that Petitioners’ claim under Count One is 
1
premature as to the putative 90-Day Class.  (Mot. at 16–18.)  Petitioners’ proposed 90-
2
Day Class consists of pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been detained for more 
3
than 90 days after receiving a final order of removal.  Defendants argue that post-removal 
4
order noncitizens cannot bring a Zadvydas claim challenging their detention until they 
5
have been detained for the presumptively reasonable six-month period.  Until then, 
6
Defendants argue, the 90-Day Class’ claim is unripe.   
7
 
8
  The issue of whether noncitizens can challenge their detention under section 
9
1231(a)(6) before the six-month period passes appears to be an open question in the 
10
Ninth Circuit.  In Zadvydas, the Supreme Court held that section 1231(a)(6) “implicitly 
11
limits an alien’s detention to a period reasonably necessary to bring about that alien’s 
12
removal.”  Id. at 689.  Recognizing the “difficult judgments” that would be left to the 
13
district court, the Supreme Court established a “presumptively reasonable period of 
14
detention” of six months.  Id. at 701.  Once an individual has been detained for six 
15
months, constitutional concerns presumptively arise, and the Supreme Court’s burden-
16
shifting framework serves as a “guide [for] lower court determinations.”  Id. at 700–701.  
17
The Supreme Court in Zadvydas did not explicitly preclude a noncitizen from challenging 
18
his detention prior to the end of the presumptively reasonable six-month period.   
19
 
20
  Defendants argue that the Ninth Circuit’s holding in Khotesouvan v. Morones 
21
“squarely” indicates that a Zadvydas claim is unripe before the six-month period.  (Mot. 
22
at 16.)  In Khotesouvan, the Ninth Circuit considered Zadvydas claims by Vietnamese 
23
and Laotian noncitizens who had been in post-removal order detention.  386 F.3d 1298, 
24
1301 (9th Cir. 2004).  At issue was whether the Government could continue to detain 
25
post-removal order petitioners who had been in custody for less than 90 days, but whose 
26
removal the Government conceded was not reasonably foreseeable.  Id. at 1299.  The 
27
28
-14- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 15 of 18   Page ID #:853
 
Ninth Circuit held that the petitioners could not raise a due process claim challenging 
1
their detention under Zadvydas “until at least 90 days of detention have passed.”  Id.  
2
 
3
  Defendants have failed to show how Zadvydas or Khotesouvan close the door on 
4
Petitioners’ claim as to the putative 90-Day Class.  The six-month Zadvydas presumption 
5
is “just that—a presumption.”  Clark v. Martinez, 543 U.S. 371, 387 (2005) (O’Connor, 
6
J., concurring).  The Supreme Court in Zadvydas outlined a “guide” for approaching 
7
these detention challenges, 533 U.S. at 700–701, not a prohibition on claims challenging 
8
detention less than six months.  Further, the petitioners in Khotesouvan were being 
9
detained pursuant to a notably different provision of section 1231.  In Khotesouvan, the 
10
petitioners were still within the statutory 90-day removal period under section 1231(a)(2), 
11
during which the Government “shall detain the alien.”  See 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(2) 
12
(emphasis added).  The 90-Day Class proposed here consists of individuals detained for 
13
more than 90 days pursuant to section 1231(a)(6), under which the Supreme Court found 
14
the discretionary “may” language posed a risk of indefinite detention.  Zadvydas, 533 
15
U.S. at 697.  In holding that a noncitizen could not challenge their detention “until at least 
16
90 days of detention have passed,” the Ninth Circuit in Khotesouvan left open the 90-Day 
17
Class Members’ claim challenging detention greater than 90 days.  Petitioners have stated 
18
a plausible claim for relief as to the 90-Day Class for the reasons already addressed in the 
19
discussion of Count One above.  
20
  
21
2.  Count Two: Individualized Bond Hearing 
22
 
23
In Count Two, Petitioners claim that even if removal is reasonably foreseeable, 
24
detention for more than six months violates section 1231 and constitutional due process 
25
where it is “without any individualized determination that [the noncitizens] pose a danger 
26
or flight risk.”  (Id. ¶¶ 72–75.)  Petitioners assert this claim on behalf of the members of 
27
the Prolonged Detention Class, i.e., all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been 
28
-15- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 16 of 18   Page ID #:854
 
or will be detained by ICE for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.  Defendants 
1
move to dismiss Count Two for failure to state a claim on the grounds that it is not 
2
supported by statute and conflicts with Supreme Court authority.  (Mot. at 18–23.)   
3
 
4
Petitioners do not assert that the text of section 1231(a)(6) itself provides for 
5
individualized bond hearings.  Rather, Petitioners assert that noncitizens facing prolonged 
6
detention under section 1231 are entitled to an individualized bond hearing based on 
7
Ninth Circuit authority in Diouf v. Napolitano.  In that case, the Ninth Circuit held that 
8
prolonged detention under section 1231(a)(6) raises “serious constitutional concerns” 
9
where it occurs “without adequate procedural protections.”  634 F.3d 1081, 1085–86 (9th 
10
Cir. 2011) (quotation marks omitted).  The court concluded that a noncitizen facing 
11
prolonged detention under § 1231(a)(6) therefore “is entitled to a bond hearing before an 
12
immigration judge.”  Id.  “[U]nless the government establishes that the alien poses a risk 
13
of flight or a danger to the community,” the noncitizen is entitled to release from 
14
detention.  Id.   
15
 
16
Defendants dispute the reach of the Ninth Circuit’s holding in Diouf and argue it 
17
has been “effectively overruled by” and is “clearly irreconcilable” with Supreme Court 
18
authority in Jennings v. Rodriquez.  (Mot. at 20.)  In Jennings, the Supreme Court held 
19
that three pre-removal order detention statutes not at issue in this litigation—8 U.S.C. §§ 
20
1225(b), 1226(a), 1226(c)—cannot be construed to require bond hearings.  138 S. Ct. 
21
830, 848–51 (2018).   Defendants argue that in light of Jennings, the Ninth Circuit in 
22
Diouf “did not plausibly interpret the statutory text” of section 1231(a)(6).  (Mot. at 20.)  
23
Defendants claim that because Diouf applied Ninth Circuit precedent that was overturned 
24
in Jennings, Jennings and Diouf are irreconcilable.  (Id. at 21.)   
25
 
26
The outcome in Jennings does not foreclose Petitioners’ claim here.  First, the 
27
Supreme Court in Jennings expressly stated that section 1231(a)(6) “differs materially” 
28
-16- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 17 of 18   Page ID #:855
 
from the three statutes at issue in that case.  138 S. Ct. at 833.  Unlike the other detention 
1
statutes, section 1231(a)(6) could plausibly be read to contain an “implicit time limit” and 
2
employed discretionary language that justified application of the constitutional avoidance 
3
doctrine.  Id. at 843–44 (citing Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 683).  Further, at least nine district 
4
courts in the Ninth Circuit have held that Diouf remains good law post-Jennings.4  This 
5
Court can disregard Diouf only if it is “clearly irreconcilable” with Jennings—a “high 
6
standard.”  See United States v. Robertson, 875 F.3d 1281, 1291 (9th Cir. 2017).  In light 
7
of the Supreme Court’s express distinguishing of section 1231(a)(6) and the authority in 
8
this Circuit to the contrary, Defendants have failed to meet that high standard here.  
9
 
10
Petitioners also assert that they are entitled to bond hearings under the Due Process 
11
Clause.  (Opp. at 18.)  Detention must be accompanied by “adequate procedural 
12
protections” to ensure that the Government’s asserted interest “outweighs the individual’s 
13
constitutionally protected interest in avoiding physical restraint.”  Zadvydas, 633 U.S. at 
14
690.  Defendants argue that under Zadvydas, post-removal order detention does not raise 
15
a due process violation until the petitioner shows he is not significantly likely to be 
16
removed in the reasonably foreseeable future.  (Opp. at 18.)  Defendants argue that 
17
because Petitioners have not made that showing here, their detention cannot raise a 
18
constitutional problem under Zadvydas.  (Id.)  However, as noted, Petitioners have 
19
alleged sufficient facts to state a claim that their removal is not reasonably foreseeable in 
20
the future.  Petitioners have alleged sufficient facts to state a claim for individualized 
21
bond hearings under Count Two. 
22
23
24                                                            
4 See Ramos v. Sessions, 2018 WL 1317276, at *3 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 13, 2018); Cortez v. Sessions, 2018 
25 WL 1510187, at *8 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 27, 2018); Borjas-Calix v. Sessions, 2018 WL 1428154, at *15 (D. 
Ariz. Mar. 22, 2018); Banos v. Asher, 2018 WL 1617706, at *1 (W.D. Wash. Apr. 4, 2018); Higareda v. 
26
Sessions, CV-18-00491-PHX-SPL (DKD) (D. Ariz. Apr. 5, 2018), Dkt. 20; Sied v. Nielsen, 2018 WL 
1876907, at *5 (N.D. Cal. Apr. 19, 2018); Mercado-Guillen v. Nielsen, 2018 WL 1876916, at *3 (N.D. 
27
Cal. Apr. 19, 2018); Hurtado-Romero v. Sessions, 2018 WL 2234500, at *2 (N.D. Cal. May 16, 2018); 
28 Gonzalez v. Sessions, 2018 WL 2688569, at *11 (N.D. Cal. June 5, 2018).  Several of these cases are on 
appeal to the Ninth Circuit. 
-17- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 66   Filed 09/06/18   Page 18 of 18   Page ID #:856
 
IV.  CONCLUSION    
1
 
2
For the foregoing reasons, Defendants’ hybrid motion to dismiss and habeas return 
3
is DENIED. 
4
 
5
 
6
 
7

02/20/2020 114 MINUTES OF Discovery Hearing held before Magistrate Judge
Gail J. Standish regarding in camera documents reviewed by the
Court. The narrow issue before the Court is whether certain
redactions applied by Respondent to twenty-five documents,
which the Court reviewed in camera, are proper. Specifically,
Petitioners challenge whether, in asserting the deliberative
process privilege as to these documents (in whole or in part),
Respondents fulfilled their obligation to produce reasonably
severable factual material. See F.T.C. v. Warner Commc'ns Inc.,
742 F.2d 1156, 1161 (9th Cir. 1984). The documents at issue are
primarily drafts of memoranda and internal analyses, and, in
general, are documents to which the deliberative process
privilege applies. (See order for details) Court Recorder: CS
Roybal Courtroom 640. (efc) (Entered: 02/20/2020)

documents.title: Order Denying Without Prejudice Petitioners' Motion for a Preliminary Injunction and for Provisional Class Certification
documents.text:
Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 40   Filed 05/23/18   Page 1 of 3   Page ID #:482

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT

CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA

SOUTHERN DIVISION

NGUYEN, NGOC HOANG, DAI

DIEP, BAO DUONG, and SIEU  )

NGUYEN, on behalf of themselves and 
)  PREJUDICE PETITIONERS’ 
all of those similarly situated, 
16 )  MOTION FOR A PRELIMINARY 
  )  INJUNCTION AND FOR 
17 )  PROVISIONAL CLASS 
    Petitioners,  )  CERTIFICATION 
18 ) 
  v.  ) 
19 ) 
 
) 
THOMAS D. HOMAN, KIRSTJEN M.

-1- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 40   Filed 05/23/18   Page 2 of 3   Page ID #:483
 
  Before the Court is Petitioners’ motion for a preliminary injunction and for 
1
provisional class certification.  (Dkt. 22.)  For the following reasons, the motion is 
2
DENIED WITHOUT PREJUDICE.1
3  
 
4
  Petitioners are citizens of Vietnam who immigrated to the United States before 
5
1995.  Petitioners are subject to orders of removal to Vietnam based on criminal 
6
convictions, and were recently placed in immigration detention pursuant to those removal 
7
orders.  On February 22, 2018, four named Petitioners, Hoang Trinh, Vu Ha, Long 
8
Nguyen, and Ngoc Hoang, initiated this habeas class action petition.  (Dkt. 1.)  
9
Petitioners alleged that their continued detention was unlawful because Vietnamese 
10
nationals who immigrated before 1995 are protected from removal proceedings under an 
11
agreement between the United States and Vietnam.  (See generally id.)   
12
 
13
  On April 25, 2018, Petitioners filed their motion for a preliminary injunction and 
14
for provisional class certification.  (Dkt. 22.)  On April 30, 2018, Respondents filed a 
15
motion to dismiss.  (Dkt. 24.)  Respondents explained that all four Petitioners named in 
16
the habeas petition have since been released from immigration detention, so their claims 
17
were moot.  (Id.)  In response, Petitioners filed a First Amended Habeas Petition and 
18
Complaint on May 11, 2018.  (Dkt. 27.)  In their amended pleading, Petitioners allege 
19
that the original four named Petitioners have been released from detention.  (Id. ¶¶ 11–
20
14.)  But the amended pleading adds three named Petitioners, Sieu Nguyen, Dai Diep, 
21
and Boa Duong, who are currently in detention.  (Id. ¶¶ 15–17.)   
22
 
23
// 
24
// 
25
26
                                                           
27
1  Having read and considered the papers presented by the parties, the Court finds this matter appropriate 
28 for disposition without a hearing.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 78; Local Rule 7-15.  Accordingly, the hearing set 
for June 11, 2018, at 1:30 p.m. is hereby vacated and off calendar. 
-2- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 40   Filed 05/23/18   Page 3 of 3   Page ID #:484
 
  On May 14, 2018, Respondents withdrew their motion to dismiss in light of 
1
Petitioners’ amended petition.  (Dkt. 28.)  Respondents now contend that Petitioners’ 
2
motion for a preliminary injunction and provisional class certification should be denied 
3
because it is based on the original habeas petition.  (Dkt. 37 at 10–12.)  The Court agrees 
4
with Respondents.  
5
 
6
  In order to warrant a grant of injunctive relief, Petitioners must show a relationship 
7
between “the injury claimed in the motion for injunctive relief and the conduct asserted in 
8
the underlying complaint.”  Pac. Radiation Oncology, LLC v. Queen’s Med. Ctr., 810 
9
F.3d 631, 636 (9th Cir. 2015).  Petitioners’ motion is based on conduct and claims 
10
asserted in their original petition with respect to the original four named Petitioners and 
11
their continued detention.  But Petitioners have since amended their petition indicating 
12
that the original four Petitioners have been released from custody.  Petitioners’ motion is 
13
therefore based on claims that no longer have legal effect.  Doe v. Unocal Corp., 27 F. 
14
Supp. 2d 1174, 1180 (C.D. Cal. 1998), aff’d and adopted, 248 F.3d 915 (9th Cir. 2001) 
15
(“It is hornbook law that an amended pleading supersedes the original, the latter being 
16
treated thereafter as non-existent.  Once amended, the original no longer performs any 
17
function as a pleading.”) (citations and quotations omitted).  Without a nexus between 
18
operative claims and the injury claimed in a motion for injunctive relief, the Court may 
19
not grant the requested injunctive relief.  Pac. Radiation Oncology, LLC, 810 F.3d at 636. 
20
 
21
 
22
  DATED:  May 23, 2018 
23
              __________________________________ 
24
                CORMAC J. CARNEY 
25
              UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
26
27
28
-3-

documents.title: Order Denying in Part and Denying in Part Petitioners' Motion for Class Certification
documents.text:
Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 1 of 20   Page ID #:939
 
 
1
 
2
 
3
 
4
 
5
 
6
 
7
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
9
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
10
 
11
)   
HOANG TRINH, VU HA, LONG 
12 )  Case No.: SACV 18-00316-CJC(GJSx) 
NGUYEN, NGOC HOANG, DAI DIEP, 
)   
13 BAO DUONG, and SIEU NGUYEN, on  )   
)   
behalf of themselves and those similarly 
14 )   
situated, 
)   
15   )   
)  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
16     Petitioners,  )  DENYING IN PART PETITIONERS’ 
)  MOTION FOR CLASS 
17   v.  )  CERTIFICATION  
) 
 
18 ) 
THOMAS D. HOMAN, KIRSTJEN M. 
) 
19 NIELSEN, JEFFERSON B. SESSIONS  ) 
) 
III, DAVID MARIN, SANDRA 
20 ) 
HUTCHENS, and JOHN DOE, 
) 
21   ) 
) 
22     Defendants.  ) 
  )   
23
 
24
I.  INTRODUCTION 
25
 
26   This putative class action challenges the Government’s practice of subjecting 
27 Vietnamese immigrants to post-removal order detention despite the remote possibility of 
28 their removal to Vietnam.  (Dkt. 27 [First Amended Habeas Corpus Petition and Class 
-1- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 2 of 20   Page ID #:940
 
Action Complaint, hereinafter “FAC”] ¶¶ 1–4.)  The named Petitioners assert that they, 
1
along with thousands of other Vietnamese refugees who immigrated to the United States 
2
before July 12, 1995 (“pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants”), have been or will be 
3
subjected to this practice.   
4
 
5
Petitioners bring two causes of action for habeas relief, declaratory relief, and 
6
injunctive relief.  (Id. ¶ 76.)  In Count One, Petitioners assert that their post-removal 
7
order detention violates federal immigration law, 8 U.S.C. § 1231, and constitutional due 
8
process where removal is not likely to occur in the foreseeable future.  (Id. ¶¶ 64–70.)  In 
9
Count Two, Petitioners assert that even where removal is reasonably foreseeable, their 
10
prolonged detention violates section 1231 and constitutional due process when it is 
11
“without any individualized determination that they pose a danger or flight risk.”  (Id. ¶¶ 
12
72–75.)   
13
 
14
Petitioners now seek to certify three putative classes of pre-1995 Vietnamese 
15
immigrants who, like them, received removal orders, faced varying periods of 
16
immigration detention, and either remain detained or face redetention by the 
17
Government.  (Dkt. 65 [Mot. for Class Cert., hereinafter “Mot.”].)  Petitioners’ three 
18
putative classes consist of (1) all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will 
19
be detained by ICE for more than 90 days after receiving removal orders (“90-Day 
20
Class”), (2) all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by 
21
ICE for more than 180 days after receiving removal orders (“180-Day Class”), and (3) all 
22
pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by ICE for more 
23
than 180 days in total without a bond hearing (“Prolonged Detention Class”).  (FAC ¶ 
24
59.)  For the following reasons, Petitioners’ motion for class certification is GRANTED 
25

II.  BACKGROUND 
1
 
2
  After the Vietnam War, the North Vietnamese government established the current 
3
Socialist Republic of Vietnam.  (Dkt. 22-12 [Declaration of Tu-Huong Nguyen-Vo, 
4
hereinafter “Nguyen-Vo Decl.”] ¶ 7.)  Beginning in 1975, waves of Vietnamese refugees 
5

6

7
refugees, including Petitioners.  (Id. ¶ 13.)   
8
 
9
  Petitioners are Vietnamese citizens who immigrated to the United States prior to 
10
July 12, 1995.  (FAC ¶ 1.)  They became lawful permanent residents years ago but, based 
11
on criminal convictions, lost their green cards and were ordered removed.  (Id. ¶ 2.)  
12

13

14

15

hereinafter “N. Hoang Decl.”] ¶¶ 8, 15, 18; Dkt. 22-7 [Declaration of Long Nguyen,

provides that “Vietnamese citizens are not subject to return to Vietnam under this

Agreement if they arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995.”  (Id. ¶¶ 2, 36; id.

III.  ANALYSIS 
1
 
2
  Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23, district courts have broad discretion to 
3
determine whether a class should be certified.  Armstrong v. Davis, 275 F.3d 849, 871 
4
n.28 (9th Cir. 2001).  Rule 23 is not merely a pleading standard—a party seeking class 
5
certification must affirmatively demonstrate compliance with the Rule by proving the 
6
requirements in fact.  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 350 (2011).  Rule 
7
23(a) provides that a case is appropriate for certification as a class action if: “(1) the class 
8
is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable; (2) there are questions of law 
9
or fact common to the class; (3) the claims or defenses of the representative parties are 
10
typical of the claims or defenses of the class; and (4) the representative parties will fairly 
11
and adequately protect the interests of the class.”  These four requirements are often 
12
referred to as numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy.  See Gen. Tel. Co. of 
13
Sw. v. Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 156 (1982).   
14
 
15
  Rule 23(b) defines different types of classes.  Leyva v. Medline Indus. Inc., 716 
16
F.3d 510, 512 (9th Cir. 2012).  In this case, Petitioners seek certification pursuant to Rule 
17
23(b)(2).  (Mot. at 2.)  Rule 23(b)(2) permits certification if “the party opposing the class 
18
has acted or refused to act on grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final 
19
injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as 
20
a whole.”  Petitioners bear the burden of satisfying the elements of Rules 23(a) and 
21
22 23(b)(2) for each of their three proposed classes.  See Zinser v. Accufix Research Inst., 
23 Inc., 253 F.3d 1180, 1186 (9th Cir. 2001).   
24  
25  
26  
27  
28 //
