Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 7 of 20   Page ID #:945
 
A. Rule 23(a) 
1
2  
3   Under Rule 23(a), Petitioners must meet the four requirements of commonality, 
4 typicality, numerosity, and adequacy.  The Court considers each requirement in turn. 
5  
6 1.  Commonality 
 
7
Under Rule 23(a)(2)’s commonality requirement, there must be “questions of law 
8
or fact common to the class.”  Petitioners must “demonstrate that the class members 
9
‘have suffered the same injury,’” not “merely that they have all suffered a violation of the 
10
same provision of law.”  Wal-Mart Stores, 564 U.S. at 350 (quoting Gen. Tel. Co., 457 
11
U.S. at 157).  Petitioners’ claim must depend on a “common contention” that is “capable 
12
of classwide resolution.”  Id.  This means “that determination of its truth or falsity will 
13
resolve an issue that is central to the validity of each one of the claims in one stroke.”  Id.   
14
 
15
  Petitioners move to certify their putative 90-Day and 180-Day Classes as to Count 
16
One.  In Count One, Petitioners assert that their post-removal order detention violates 
17
federal immigration law, 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6), and constitutional due process where 
18
their removal is not significantly likely to occur in the reasonably foreseeable future.  
19
(FAC ¶¶ 64–70.)  Section 1231 provides that after an alien is ordered removed, the 
20
Government “shall remove the alien from the United States within a period of 90 days.”  
21
8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(1)(A).  During the 90-day removal period, the Government “shall 
22
detain the alien.”  Id. § 1231(a)(2).  Once the 90-day removal period ends, the 
23
Government may continue to detain certain noncitizens, such as Petitioners, whose 
24
criminal convictions render them removable.  Id. § 1231(a)(6).  Section 1231(a)(6) does 
25
not, however, authorize the Government to detain a noncitizen indefinitely.  Zadvydas, 
26
533 U.S. at 688–702.  Rather, the statute, “read in light of the Constitution’s demands, 
27
limits an alien’s post-removal-period detention to a period reasonably necessary to bring 
28
-7- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 8 of 20   Page ID #:946
 
about the alien’s removal.”  Id. at 689.  Recognizing the “difficult judgments” that would 
1
be left to a district court, the Supreme Court held that six months is a “presumptively” 
2
reasonable period of detention.  Id. at 701.  If after six months, the noncitizen provides 
3
“good reason to believe that there is no significant likelihood of removal in the 
4
reasonably foreseeable future,” the Government “must respond with evidence sufficient 
5
to rebut that showing.”  Id.  If the Government fails to do so, it cannot subject the 
6
noncitizen to continued detention.  See id. 
7
 
8
Petitioners’ 90-Day and 180-Day Class claims present common questions that will 
9
“resolve an issue that is central to the validity of each one of the claims in one stroke.”  
10
See Walmart Stores, 564 U.S. at 350.  The resolution of Petitioners’ claim as to the 90-
11
Day Class presents at least one common question: whether the class members may bring 
12
a Zadvydas claim after the 90-day removal period but before the presumptively 
13
reasonable six-month period.  (Mot. at 16.)  Petitioners seek a uniform declaration that 
14
the 90-Day Class has overcome Zadvydas’ “six-month presumption of reasonableness,” 
15
shifting the burden to the Government to show that the putative members’ removal is 
16
reasonably foreseeable.  (Id. at 24; Dkt. 71 [Pets.’ Reply, hereinafter “Reply”] at 10.)  As 
17
this Court stated in denying the Government’s motion to dismiss, whether a noncitizen 
18
can challenge post-removal order detention under Zadvydas prior to the six-month period 
19
appears to be an open question in the Ninth Circuit.  (Dkt. 66 at 14.)  Answering that 
20
question, among others, will determine whether Petitioners’ claim as to the putative 90-
21
Day Class can proceed.   
22
 
23
Petitioners’ claim as to the 180-Day Class likewise presents at least one common 
24
question: whether the 2008 Agreement and “Vietnam’s historical practice” of refusing 
25
repatriation of pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants allows Petitioners to satisfy their initial 
26
burden under Zadvydas.  (Mot. at 14–15.)  If this question is answered in the affirmative, 
27
the burden under Zadvydas would shift to the Government to provide evidence that the 
28
-8- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 9 of 20   Page ID #:947
 
putative class members’ removal is reasonably foreseeable.  See Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 
1
701.  The fact that the Government now concedes that Vietnam will not accept pre-1995 
2
Vietnamese immigrants does not render this question moot.  Many of the pre-1995 
3
Vietnamese immigrants remain in detention, and those already released can be redetained 
4
at any time.  Indeed, the Government has explicitly reserved its right to redetain these 
5
individuals.  (See Bernacke Decl. IV ¶ 3.)   
6
 
7
  Petitioners move to certify their putative Prolonged Detention Class as to Count 
8
Two.  In Count Two, Petitioners claim that even if their removal is reasonably 
9
foreseeable, detention for more than six months violates section 1231 and constitutional 
10
due process where it is “without any individualized determination that [the noncitizens] 
11
pose a danger or flight risk.”  (FAC ¶¶ 72–75.)  Petitioners’ Prolonged Detention Class 
12
includes individuals who have been or will be detained for more than 180 days in total, 
13
“including days in detention both before and after a final removal order.”  (Mot. at 8, 10.)  
14
Accordingly, if a pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrant was detained for 180 days under 8 
15
U.S.C. § 1226 (pre-removal order detention statute) and only one day under 8 U.S.C. § 
16
1231 (post-removal order detention statute), the individual would fall into the proposed 
17
class.   
18
 
19
Petitioners assert that noncitizens facing prolonged detention under section 1231 
20
are entitled to an individualized bond hearing based on Ninth Circuit authority in Diouf v. 
21
Napolitano.  In that case, the court held that prolonged detention under section 1231(a)(6) 
22
raises “serious constitutional concerns” where it occurs “without adequate procedural 
23
protections.”  634 F.3d 1081, 1085–86 (9th Cir. 2011) (quotation marks omitted).  The 
24
court concluded that a noncitizen facing prolonged detention under section 1231(a)(6) 
25
therefore “is entitled to a bond hearing before an immigration judge.”  Id.  “[U]nless the 
26
government establishes that the alien poses a risk of flight or a danger to the community,” 
27
the noncitizen is entitled to release from detention.  Id.  In its motion to dismiss 
28
-9-

Petitioners’ FAC, the Government contended that Diouf was “effectively overruled by” 
1
Jennings v. Rodriguez.  (Dkt. 56 at 20.)  In Jennings, the Supreme Court held that three 
2
pre-removal order detention statutes cannot be construed to require bond hearings.  138 
3
S. Ct. 830, 848–51 (2018).  In light of Jennings, the Government argued, the Ninth 
4
Circuit in Diouf did not “plausibly interpret the statutory text” of section 1231.  (Dkt. 56

at 20.)

The Government claims that the differences between pre-removal order and post-

removal order detention statutes “preclude” a finding that common answers can drive the

resolution of the Prolonged Detention Class’s claim.  (Opp. at 14.)  The Court disagrees.

The Government’s argument goes to the merits of Petitioners’ claim under Count Two,

not to class certification.  Regardless of which party is correct, whether Petitioners’

putative Prolonged Detention Class is entitled to a bond hearing presents a “common

Because common answers will drive the resolution of Petitioners’ class claims,

23(a).

2.  Typicality 
19
 
20
Under Rule 23(a)(3), the named Petitioners’ claims or defenses must be “typical of 
21
the claims or defenses of the class.”  “The test of typicality ‘is whether other members 
22
have the same or similar injury, whether the action is based on conduct which is not 
23
unique to the named Petitioners, and whether other class members have been injured by 
24
the same course of conduct.’”  Ellis v. Costco Wholesale Corp., 657 F.3d 970, 984 (9th 
25
Cir. 2011) (quoting Hanon v. Dataproducts Corp., 976 F.2d 497, 508 (9th Cir. 1992)).   
26
Typicality aims to ensure that “the interest of the named representative aligns with the 
27
interests of the class.”  Hanon, 976 F.2d at 508.  “Under the rule’s permissive standards, 
28

representative claims are ‘typical’ if they are reasonably coextensive with those of absent

class members; they need not be substantially identical.”  Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 
2
F.3d 1011, 1020 (9th Cir. 1998).

foreseeable.  Petitioners’ classes, by their nature, are subject to fluctuation and potentially include 
28 individuals not currently in detention.  Although the Government has suddenly decided to release pre-
1995 Vietnamese immigrants, it continues to explicitly reserve its right to redetain Petitioners.  
-14- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 15 of 20   Page ID #:953
 
2015).  Here, Petitioners satisfy both requirements.  There are no conflicts between the 
1
interests of the named Petitioners and those of the putative class members.  Named 
2
Petitioners share with the putative class members an interest in minimizing detention and 
3
protecting their due process rights.  The named Petitioners have also retained counsel 
4
who are well qualified in immigrant rights and class-action litigation.  (See Dkts. 22-2 
5
[Declaration of Raymond Cardozo], 22-10 [Declaration of Phi Nguyen], 22-11 
6
[Declaration of Jingni Zhao].)  There is no indication that Petitioners’ counsel will not 
7
continue to vigorously protect Petitioners’ interests.  Petitioners’ three putative classes 
8
satisfy the four requirements under Rule 23(a). 
9
 
10
B. Rule 23(b)(2) 
11
 
12
Petitioners seek certification pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2).  Under Rule 23(b)(2), 
13
Petitioners must show that “the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on 
14
grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding 
15
declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole.”  Rule 23(b)(2) “applies 
16
only when a single injunction or declaratory judgment would provide relief to each 
17
member of the class.”  Wal-Mart Stores, 564 U.S. at 360.  “The rule does not require [the 
18
Court] to examine the viability or bases of class members’ claims for declaratory and 
19
injunctive relief, but only to look at whether class members seek uniform relief from a 
20
practice applicable to all of them.”  Rodriguez v. Hayes, 591 F.3d 1105, 1125 (9th Cir. 
21
2010).  The Court considers each putative class in turn.   
22
 
23
The putative 90-Day Class members have faced uniform conduct capable of 
24
uniform relief.  First, they have been subjected to the same allegedly unlawful conduct: 
25
post-removal order detention for more than 90 days where removal to Vietnam is not 
26
significantly likely in the reasonably foreseeable future.  Further, they seek a uniform 
27
remedy.  Petitioners seek declaratory relief stating that (1) the Class can challenge its 
28
-15- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 16 of 20   Page ID #:954
 
detention under Zadvydas before the presumptively reasonable six-month period, and (2) 
1
that the Class has shown its removal is not significantly likely in the foreseeable future, 
2
shifting the burden to the Government to demonstrate that removal is reasonably 
3
foreseeable.  (Mot. at 23–24.)   
4
 
5
 The Government does not dispute that Petitioners’ proposed declaratory relief 
6
would provide relief to each member of the putative 90-Day Class.  Rather, they contend 
7
that if this Court granted that relief, it would contradict the holding in Zadvydas.  
8
Zadvydas, the Government argues, “requires an alien to make an initial showing, based 
9
on current facts and circumstances, of ‘good reason to believe’ that his removal is not 
10
reasonably foreseeable.”  (Opp. at 13 [emphasis in original].)  By issuing a classwide 
11
declaration regarding the foreseeability of pre-1995 immigrants’ removal under 
12
Zadvydas, the Government contends that the Court would issue an improper “classwide, 
13
per se predetermination that pre-1995 [Vietnamese immigrants] cannot be removed.”  
14
(Id. at 10.)  
15
   
16
  The Government mischaracterizes Petitioners’ proposed declaratory relief.  
17
Petitioners do not seek a “per se predetermination” that all pre-1995 Vietnamese 
18
immigrants cannot be removed.  Petitioners seek an order declaring that the removal of 
19
pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants is not reasonably foreseeable based on the facts 
20
currently before the Court.  If the Court declares that the current circumstances indicate 
21
“good reason to believe” that pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants’ removal is not 
22
significantly likely in the reasonably foreseeable future, the Government would have the 
23
opportunity to rebut that showing under Zadvydas.  In any event, the Government fails to 
24
identify any individualized criteria that would definitively make removal more or less 
25
foreseeable for a pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrant.  To date, they have addressed the 
26
putative class members’ likelihood of removal on a groupwide basis.  Initially they 
27
argued that classwide relief was inappropriate because pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants 
28
-16- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 17 of 20   Page ID #:955
 
could be removed under a new verbal understanding with Vietnam.  Now they claim 
1
classwide relief is inappropriate because pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants definitively 
2
cannot be removed under another new understanding.  Whether or not Petitioners will 
3
ultimately prevail on the merits, the adjudication of their request would provide or deny 
4
“uniform relief from a practice applicable to all of” the putative 90-Day Class members.  
5
See Rodriguez, 591 F.3d at 1125.  The Court grants certification of the 90-Day Class as to 
6
the isolated issues of whether the Class has overcome the six-month presumption of 
7
reasonableness and met its burden under Zadvydas.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4) (“When 
8
appropriate, an action may be brought or maintained as a class action with respect to 
9
particular issues.”)   
10
 
11
On behalf of the 180-Day Class, Petitioners seek injunctive relief, or in the 
12
alternative, declaratory relief.  Petitioners’ proposed injunctive relief enjoins the 
13
Government from detaining pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants for more than 180 days 
14
“absent proof that Vietnam has agreed to repatriate” them.  (Mot. at 8, 21; Reply at 4, 7.)  
15
In the alternative, Petitioners ask this Court to declare that the 180-Day Class members, 
16
like the 90-Day Class members, have met their initial burden under Zadvydas by showing 
17
that their removal is not significantly likely in the reasonably foreseeable future.  (Mot. at 
18
23.) 
19
 
20
  Petitioners’ proposed injunctive relief contradicts Zadvydas and intrudes on 
21
legislative and executive branch authority.  Under Zadvydas, Petitioners can challenge 
22
their detention where they show their removal is not significantly likely in the reasonably 
23
foreseeable future.  Petitioners’ injunctive relief, however, asks this Court to prevent the 
24
Government from detaining pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants unless the Government 
25
makes an evidentiary showing that Vietnam has agreed to repatriate them.  The Supreme 
26
Court in Zadvydas did not imbue the courts with such expansive authority to interfere 
27
with the Government’s ability to effectuate federal immigration law.  Indeed, the 
28
-17- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 18 of 20   Page ID #:956
 
Supreme Court explicitly counseled against such an intrusion.  See Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 
1
659 (recognizing that the “Judicial Branch must defer to Executive and Legislative 
2
Branch decisionmaking” in immigration law); id. at 700 (stating that a court’s review in 
3
these cases “must take appropriate account of the greater immigration-related expertise of 
4
the Executive Branch”).  The Supreme Court was careful to acknowledge that the courts 
5
have no authority to “deny the right of Congress to remove aliens, to subject them to 
6
supervision with conditions when released from detention, or to incarcerate them where 
7
appropriate for violations of those conditions.”  Id. at 659.  The Supreme Court simply 
8
addressed the issue of “whether aliens that the Government finds itself unable to remove 
9
are to be condemned to an indefinite term of imprisonment within the United States.”  Id.  
10
Under Zadvydas, Petitioners may challenge that “indefinite . . . imprisonment” once it 
11
occurs.    
12
 
13
In the alternative, Petitioners seek declaratory relief that mirrors the relief sought 
14
on behalf of the 90-Day Class.  Specifically, they ask this Court to declare that the 180-
15
Day Class members have met their burden under Zadvydas to show “good reason to 
16
believe that there is no significant likelihood of removal in the reasonably foreseeable 
17
future.”  533 U.S. at 701.  Unlike Petitioners’ proposed injunctive relief, this declaratory 
18
relief can be issued on a classwide basis without categorically preventing the Government 
19
from redetaining pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants.4  At 180 days of post-removal order 
20
detention, the Government could continue detaining a pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrant if 
21
Vietnam issued a travel document or otherwise agreed to repatriation.  Petitioners have 
22
met their burden of showing that the putative 180-Day Class members have faced 
23
uniform conduct addressable by uniform declaratory relief under Rule 23(b)(2). 
24
25                                                            
4 The Government contends that Supreme Court authority in Jama v. ICE counsels against imposing 
26
“improper restriction[s] on the Government’s authority to remove post-order aliens.”  (Opp. at 10 [citing 
Jama v. ICE, 543 U.S. 335, 344 (2005)].)  However, that case was not about the Government’s detention 
27
authority.  The issue was whether ICE was authorized to remove noncitizens to Somalia, which lacked a 
28 functioning government to provide advance consent.  Here, Petitioners’ proposed relief does not 
interfere with noncitizens’ removal.  It concerns prolonged detention where their removal is unlikely. 
-18- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 19 of 20   Page ID #:957
 
The Government contends that declaratory relief, without injunctive relief, is 
1
meaningless.  At the hearing, counsel for the Government argued that because any 
2
declaratory relief stating that the class members’ removal is not reasonably foreseeable 
3
under Zadvydas would be limited to the facts and circumstances currently before the 
4
Court, that relief would not have any weight if the circumstances affecting their removal 
5
change.  Although declaratory relief on behalf of the 90-Day and 180-Day Classes would 
6
be limited in its reach, it is not without teeth.  Declaratory relief stating that the class 
7
members have met their initial burden under Zadvydas would allow them to challenge 
8
more easily on an individual or perhaps collective basis the constitutionality of further 
9
detention when Vietnam continues to refuse their repatriation.  The Court recognizes that 
10
it cannot interfere with the Government’s authority to detain individuals pursuant to 
11
federal immigration law, but it can and must intervene where detention deprives 
12
individuals of their constitutional rights.  Although the Government now has conceded 
13
that class members’ removal to Vietnam is not likely in the reasonably foreseeable future, 
14
the Government has not conceded that it violated these individuals’ constitutional rights 
15
when it detained them with the knowledge that they could not and would not be removed 
16
to Vietnam.  And more importantly, many of the class members still remain in detention, 
17
and the Government has explicitly reserved its right to redetain all of those it has recently 
18
released.  Contrary to the Government’s assertion, the proposed declaratory relief is not 
19
meaningless.    
20
 
21
Finally, Petitioners have also shown that the putative Prolonged Detention Class 
22
members have faced uniform conduct capable of uniform relief.  On behalf of the 
23
Prolonged Detention Class, Petitioners seek individualized bond hearings for pre-1995 
24
Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained for more than 180 days in 
25
total.  The putative class members have been subjected to a uniform practice: detention 
26
for more than 180 days in total without a bond hearing.  The requested relief—bond 
27
hearings—would “provide relief to each member of the class.”  See Wal-Mart Stores, 564 
28
-19- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 75   Filed 10/18/18   Page 20 of 20   Page ID #:958
 
U.S. at 360.  Courts in this Circuit have routinely employed Rule 23(b)(2) to certify 
1
claims involving the Government’s blanket refusal to conduct bond hearings.  See, e.g., 
2
Preap v. Johnson, 303 F.R.D. 566, 571 (N.D. Cal. 2014) (holding that “the class action 
3
mechanism easily and efficiently establishes the right of all class members to a bond 
4
hearing”); Riviera v. Holder, 307 F.R.D. 539, 551 (W.D. Wash. 2015); Hernandez v. 
5
Lynch, 2016 WL 7116611, at *19 (C.D. Cal. Nov. 10, 2016), aff’d sub nom. Hernandez v. 
6
Sessions, 872 F.3d 976 (9th Cir. 2017).  Whether Petitioners’ 180-Day Class is entitled to 
7
individualized bond hearings here is a question for the merits.  Petitioners have satisfied 
8
their burden of showing that the putative Prolonged Detention Class is appropriate for 
9
certification under Rule 23(b)(2). 
10
 
11
IV.  CONCLUSION    
12
 
13
For the foregoing reasons, Petitioners’ motion for class certification is GRANTED 
14
IN PART and DENIED IN PART.  The Court hereby designates Petitioners’ counsel as 
15
class counsel and appoints the named Petitioners as class representatives.   
16
 
17
 
18
 
19
  DATED:  October 18, 2018 
20
              __________________________________ 
21
                CORMAC J. CARNEY 
22
              UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
23

Case No. 8:18-cv-316  – 2 – 
HABEAS CORPUS CLASS ACTION PETITION AND CLASS 
ACTION COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 27   Filed 05/11/18   Page 3 of 26   Page ID #:385
 
1 INTRODUCTION 
2 1.  This  class  action  habeas  petition  and  complaint  for  declaratory  and 
3 injunctive relief is brought on behalf of Petitioners, who fled war-torn Vietnam, were 
4 accepted by the United States as refugees before July 12, 1995 and have resided in 
5 the United States since they were young children or teenagers. As a result of abrupt 
6 and unlawful actions by Respondents, Petitioners currently face unwarranted and 
7 indefinite immigration detention. 
8 2.  Petitioners  became  lawful  permanent  residents  of  this  country  many 
9 years ago but, based on criminal convictions, lost their green cards and were ordered 
10 removed from the United States. Although Petitioners have final orders of removal, 
ware  11 they cannot be repatriated under the existing repatriation agreement between the 
Dela
LLP  n the State of  1123 UStnaitteesd a Sntda ttehse  aGndo vVerinetmnaemnt.  oSfe teh eA gSroeceimaleisntt  RBeeptuwbeleicn  othf eV Gieotnvaemrn monen tth oe fA thcec eUptnaintecde  
TH med i
ED SMInership for 14 of  the  Return  of  Vietnamese  Citizens.1  The  agreement  does  not  allow  for  the 
REy part 15 repatriation of Vietnamese immigrants who came to the United States before July 12, 
mited liabilit 16 1995 (“pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants”), a population that is largely comprised of 
A li 17 refugees  who  fled  Vietnam  after  the  war  to  escape  persecution  under  the  new 
18 communist regime.   
19 3.  United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”) has had a 
20 longstanding practice of releasing pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants with final orders 
21 of removal due to legal constraints on their detention authority. Recognizing that pre-
22 1995  Vietnamese  immigrants  are  “not  subject  to  return  to  Vietnam”  under  the 
23 repatriation agreement, ICE has typically released these immigrants on orders of 
24 supervision within 90 days of their removal orders becoming final. The repatriation 
25
26                                                
1 This agreement can be found on the U.S. Department of State’s website.  See 
27 Attachment A (Agreement Concerning the Acceptance of the Return of Vietnamese 
Citizens, U.S.- NAM., Jan. 22, 2008, 08 – 43, https://www.state.gov/documents/ 
28 organization/108921.pdf). 
Case No. 8:18-cv-316  – 1 – 
HABEAS CORPUS CLASS ACTION PETITION AND CLASS 
ACTION COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 27   Filed 05/11/18   Page 4 of 26   Page ID #:386
 
1
agreement  has  thus  given  thousands  of  pre-1995  Vietnamese  immigrants  the 
2
opportunity to return to their families and communities to rebuild their lives. 
3
4.  In  2017,  ICE  abruptly  departed  from  past  enforcement  practices 
4
pertaining to pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants with final orders of removal. ICE 
5
began subjecting pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants to much longer periods of post-
6
removal order detention, in some cases as long as eleven months. ICE also began re-
7
detaining  without  notice  pre-1995  Vietnamese  immigrants  all  across  the  United 
8
States who had been living peaceably in their communities on orders of supervision 
9
for years or decades. 
10
5.  ICE’s  enforcement  tactics  have  sown  fear  in  Vietnamese  refugee 
ware  11
Dela communities around the country. Immigrants from other countries that have also 
LLP  n the State of  1123 historically  refused  to  accept  immigrants  for  repatriation,  including  Cambodia, 
TH med i Somalia, and Iraq, are similarly experiencing indiscriminate ICE arrests, which are 
ED SMInership for 14 the subjects of pending legal actions as well.    See, e.g., Nak Kim Chhoeun v.  David 
REmited liability part 1156 M01a8r9i8n-, CUJnCit e(Gd JSStxat)e. s District Court, Central District of California, Case No. 8:17-cv-
A li 17
6.  When this action was filed on February 22, 2018, Petitioners’ counsel 
18
were aware of approximately 40 pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants with final orders 
19
of  removal  across  the  country  who  were  beyond  90  days  of  post-removal  order 
20
detention. The total number of similarly situated individuals was likely much larger. 
21
Since  then,  Petitioners’  counsel  have  learned  of  additional  pre-1995  Vietnamese 
22
immigrants  who  have  reached  90  days  of  post-removal  order  detention.  On 
23
information  and  belief,  ICE  intends  to  continue  to  detain  pre-1995  Vietnamese 
24
immigrants  with  final  orders  of  removal.  The  number  of  Vietnamese  with  final 
25
orders of removal who are at risk of future detention is between 8,000 and 10,000. 
26
Based on ICE estimates from 2008, an overwhelming percentage of these individuals 
27
arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995.    
28
Case No. 8:18-cv-316  – 2 – 
HABEAS CORPUS CLASS ACTION PETITION AND CLASS 
ACTION COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 27   Filed 05/11/18   Page 5 of 26   Page ID #:387
 
1
7.  ICE has undertaken its detention campaign without any evidence that 
2
Vietnam  will  accept  pre-1995  Vietnamese  immigrants  that  have  been  or  will  be 
3
detained. The repatriation agreement has not been rescinded or modified by either 
4
country. Given Vietnam’s longstanding policy of categorically denying repatriation 
5
to  pre-1995  Vietnamese  immigrants,  memorialized  in  the  existing  and  valid 
6
repatriation  agreement,  detention  of  Petitioners  without  an  individualized  and 
7
specific showing that Vietnam actually intends to accept them is unlawful. 
8
8.  Additionally,  ICE  has  kept  pre-1995  Vietnamese  immigrants  in 
9
detention past 180 days without providing them any meaningful custody review to 
10
determine whether continued detention is warranted because they pose a danger or 
ware  11
Dela flight risk. ICE cannot lawfully hold Petitioners in prolonged detention absent an 
LLP  n the State of  1123 individualized showing of danger or flight risk before a neutral decision maker.   
TH med i JURISDICTION 
ED SMInership for 14 9.  This  Court  has  subject  matter  jurisdiction  under  28  U.S.C.  §  2241 
REmited liability part 1156 (2h8a bUe.aSs. Cco. r§p u1s3)3, 1th (ef eSduesrpael nqsuioenst iColna)u, saen odf  2A8r tUic.lSe. CI .o f§  t1h3e 6U1n (imteadn Sdtaamteuss C).o Tnhstei tuCtoiounrt,  
A li 17
may also grant relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201-02 (Declaratory Judgment Act) and 
18
28 U.S.C. § 1651 (All Writs Act). 
19
VENUE 
20
10.  Venue is proper in the Central District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 
21
1391(e)  because  Respondents  are  federal  officers  sued  in  their  official  capacity; 
22
Respondents Marin and Hutchens are based in this district; Petitioners Hoang Trinh, 
23
Vu Ha, and Dai Diep and numerous class members reside in this district; Petitioners 
24
Dai Diep, Bao Duong, and Sieu Nguyen and numerous class members are currently 
25
detained  in  this  district;  Petitioners  Hoang  Trinh  and  Vu  Ha  were  previously 
26
detained in this district; and a substantial part of the events or omissions giving rise 
27
to these claims occurred in this district. Venue is also proper under 28 U.S.C. §§ 
28
Case No. 8:18-cv-316  – 3 – 
HABEAS CORPUS CLASS ACTION PETITION AND CLASS 
ACTION COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 27   Filed 05/11/18   Page 6 of 26   Page ID #:388
 
1
2241 et seq., as Respondents exercise control over Petitioners. Armentero v. INS, 340 
2
F.3d 1058, 1069-70 (9th Cir. 2003), withdrawn on reh’g, 382 F.3d 1153 (9th Cir. 
3
2004) (explaining why “practicality, efficiency, and the interests of justice” demand 
4
relaxation  of  immediate  custodian  rule  in  habeas  challenges  to  immigration 
5
detention);  see  also  Roman  v.  Ashcroft,  340  F.3d  314,  319  (6th  Cir.  2003) 
6
(recognizing that while ICE Field Office Director is generally the proper respondent 
7
for  immigration  habeas  petitioners,  higher  level  ICE  officials  may  be  proper 
8
respondents in extraordinary circumstances); Vasquez v. Reno, 233 F.3d 688, 696 
9
(1st Cir. 2000). 
10
PARTIES 
ware  11
Dela 11.  Petitioner  Hoang  Trinh  is  a  41-year-old  resident  of  Orange  County, 
LLP  n the State of  1123 California who legally entered the United States from Vietnam as a four-year-old 
TH med i refugee in 1980. He subsequently adjusted his status to become a lawful permanent 
ED SMInership for 14 resident. His parents, now married for more than 50 years, raised a large Catholic 
REmited liability part 1156 ffaammiillyy —buHsoinaensgs :a nad  nheiisg hsbixo rhsiosotedr sb—akthearyt .c eHnotearnegd  laartoeru nmd ahrreilepdin  agn bdu  nilodw a  htharsi vtiwngo  
A li 17
children,  an  18-year-old  daughter  who  attends  California  State  University,  Long 
18
Beach, and a 13-year-old son. Hoang’s wife, two children, parents, and six sisters are 
19
all United States citizens. Hoang has no remaining family in Vietnam. In early 2015, 
20

mited liabilit 16 25.  Following a final order of removal, ICE is directed by statute to detain 
A li 17 an individual for 90 days in order to effectuate removal.  8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(2). This 
18 90-day period, also known as “the removal period,” generally commences as soon as 
19 a  removal  order  becomes  administratively  final.  Id.  § 1231(a)(1)(A),  § 
20 1231(a)(1)(B). 
21 26.  If ICE fails to remove an individual during the 90-day removal period, 
22 the  law  requires  ICE  to  release  the  individual  under  conditions  of  supervision, 
23 including periodic reporting. Id. § 1231(a)(3) (“If the alien . . . is not removed within 
24 the  removal  period,  the  alien,  pending  removal,  shall  be  subject  to 
25 supervision.”). Limited exceptions to this rule exist. Specifically, ICE “may” detain 
26 an individual beyond 90 days if the individual was ordered removed on criminal 
27 grounds or is determined to pose a danger or flight risk. Id. § 1231(a)(6). However, 
28 ICE’s  authority  to  detain  an  individual  beyond  the  removal  period  under  such

4 FACTS 
5 Vietnam’s Repatriation Agreement with the United States 
6 33.  In 2008, after ten years of negotiation, Vietnam and the United States 
7 executed a repatriation agreement to govern the repatriation of certain Vietnamese 
8 immigrants with final orders of removal to Vietnam. Before this agreement was 
9 negotiated, Vietnam refused to repatriate the overwhelming majority of Vietnamese 
10 immigrants ordered removed from the United States.   
ware  11 34.  Vietnam and the United States stipulated that the repatriation agreement

mited liabilit 16 35.  Upon information and belief, the repatriation agreement has not been 
A li 17 terminated or modified by either Vietnam or the United States. 
18 36.  The  repatriation  agreement  does  not  permit  the  repatriation  of 
19 Vietnamese  immigrants  who  came  to  the  United  States  before  July  12,  1995.  It 
20 expressly stipulates that “Vietnamese citizens are not subject to return to Vietnam 
21 under this Agreement if they arrived in the United States before July 12, 1995.” See 
22 Agreement,  Article  2:    Removable  Persons  and  Conditions  of  Acceptance.    The 
23 categorical exemption of pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants from repatriation reflects 
24 humanitarian considerations related to the United States’ role in the Vietnam War, 
25 the subsequent resettlement of Vietnamese refugees in America, and the continuing 
26 tension between the Vietnamese government and the Vietnamese refugees who were 
27 forced to flee their homes to avoid profound hardship and persecution after the war.

37.  The end of the Vietnam War caused hundreds of thousands of South 
2

3
persecution  and  death.    Other  Vietnamese  immigrants  who  resettled  in  America 
4
before July 12, 1995 were accepted to the United States to reunite with their loved 
5
ones or for other humanitarian reasons. The Vietnamese refugees who fled to the 
6

7

8
their lives under the new communist government and the hundreds of thousands of 
9

10
escape communist re-education camps and other forms of political persecution.

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 1 of 26   Page ID #:2552

behalf of themselves and those similarly 
14 )

)

)  ORDER ON CROSS MOTIONS FOR 
16     Petitioners,  )  SUMMARY JUDGMENT [Dkts. 119, 
)  124]  
17   v.  ) 
) 
 
18 ) 
THOMAS D. HOMAN, KIRSTJEN M. 
) 
19 NIELSEN, JEFFERSON B. SESSIONS  )

III, DAVID MARIN, SANDRA 
20 ) 
HUTCHENS, and JOHN DOE, 
) 
21   ) 
) 
22     Respondents.  ) 
  )   
23
 
24
I.  INTRODUCTION 
25
 
26   This class action challenges the government’s practice of subjecting Vietnamese 
27 immigrants to detention despite the remote possibility of their removal to Vietnam.  (Dkt. 
28 27 [First Amended Habeas Corpus Petition and Class Action Complaint, hereinafter 
-1- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 2 of 26   Page ID #:2553
 
“FAC”] ¶¶ 1–4.)  The named Petitioners assert that they, along with hundreds of other 
1
Vietnamese citizens who immigrated to the United States before July 12, 1995 (“pre-
2
1995 Vietnamese immigrants”), were subjected to this practice.   
3
 
4
Now before the Court are cross motions for summary judgment on one of the two 
5
counts asserted in the FAC.  (See Dkt. 119-1 [Petitioners’ Memorandum in Support of 
6
Motion for Summary Judgment, hereinafter “Mot.”]; Dkt. 124 [Respondents’ Cross-
7
Motion and Opposition, hereinafter “Cross Mot.”].)  For the following reasons, 
8
Petitioners’ motion is DENIED IN SUBSTANTIAL PART, and Respondents’ cross-
9
motion is GRANTED IN SUBSTANTIAL PART.1 
10
 
11
II.  BACKGROUND 
12
 
13
A.  Legal Background  
14
 
15
  Federal immigration law provides that after a removal order becomes final, the 
16
government “shall remove the alien from the United States within a period of 90 days.”  8 
17
U.S.C § 1231(a)(1)(A).  This ninety-day period is often referred to as the “initial removal 
18
period” and during it, the government “shall detain the alien.”  Id. § 1231(a)(2).  In some 
19
circumstances, federal immigration authorities can continue to detain an alien beyond the 
20
initial removal period.  Specifically, section 1231(a)(6) allows the government to detain 
21
certain enumerated classes of aliens—including those were ordered removal due to 
22
criminal convictions—for more than ninety days.  Id. § 1231(a)(6).  In Zadvydas v. 
23
Davis, 533 U.S. 678 (2001), the Court addressed the question of how long the 
24
government can detain an alien pursuant to section 1231(a)(6).   
25
26
 
27
1 The Court finds this matter appropriate for disposition without a hearing.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 78; Local 
28 Rule 7-15.  Accordingly, the hearing set for June 15, 2020, at 1:30 p.m. is hereby vacated and off 
calendar. 
-2- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 3 of 26   Page ID #:2554
 
 
1
  The Zadvydas Court began by rejecting the government’s position that section 
2
1231(a)(6) permitted indefinite detention following the initial removal period.  See id.  It 
3
held that “[a] statute that permitted indefinite detention of an alien would raise a serious 
4
constitutional problem,” and instead determined that section 1231(a)(6) “implicitly limits 
5
an alien’s detention to a period reasonably necessary to bring about that alien’s removal.”  
6
Id. at 679.  Thus, “once removal is no longer foreseeable, continued detention is no 
7
longer authorized by [section 1231(a)(6)].”  Id. at 699.   
8
 
9
  The Court went on to institute a framework that would govern future challenges to 
10
section 1231(a)(6) detention.  “[F]or the sake of uniform administration in the federal 
11
courts,” the Court found that post-removal detention was “presumptively reasonable” for 
12
the first six months.  Id. at 700–01.  When that “presumptively reasonable” six-month 
13
period ends, aliens seeking release from custody bear the initial burden of providing 
14
“good reason to believe that there is no significant likelihood of removal in the 
15
reasonably foreseeable future.”  Id. at 701; see Banda v. McAleenan, 385 F. Supp. 3d 
16
1099, 1117 (W.D. Wash. 2019) (explaining that “at six months, the burden is on the 
17
detainee—not the government—to establish a basis for release”).  Once that initial 
18
showing is made, the burden shifts to the Government to respond with evidence sufficient 
19
to rebut it.  See Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 701.   
20
 
21
B.  The History of U.S.-Vietnam Repatriation Relations 
22
 
23
  After the Vietnam War, the North Vietnamese government established the current 
24

III.  LEGAL STANDARD  
4
 
5
The Court may grant summary judgment on “each claim or defense—or the part of 
6
each claim or defense—on which summary judgment is sought.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a).  
7
Summary judgment is proper where the pleadings, the discovery and disclosure materials 
8
on file, and any affidavits show that “there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact 
9
and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.”  Id.; see also Celotex Corp. v. 
10
Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 322 (1986).  The party seeking summary judgment bears the initial 
11
burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.  Celotex, 477 
12
U.S. at 325.  A factual issue is “genuine” when there is sufficient evidence such that a 
13
reasonable trier of fact could resolve the issue in the nonmovant’s favor.  Anderson v. 
14
Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A fact is “material” when its resolution 
15
might affect the outcome of the suit under the governing law, and is determined by 
16
looking to the substantive law.  Id.  “Factual disputes that are irrelevant or unnecessary 
17
will not be counted.”  Id. at 249. 
18
 
19
  In considering a motion for summary judgment, the court must examine all the 
20
evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party, and draw all justifiable 
21
inferences in its favor.  Id.; United States v. Diebold, Inc., 369 U.S. 654, 655 (1962); T.W. 
22
Elec. Serv., Inc. v. Pac. Elec. Contractors Ass’n, 809 F.2d 626, 630–31 (9th Cir. 1987).  
23
The court does not make credibility determinations, nor does it weigh conflicting 
24
evidence.  Eastman Kodak Co. v. Image Tech. Servs., Inc., 504 U.S. 451, 456 (1992).  
25
But conclusory and speculative testimony in affidavits and moving papers is insufficient 
26
27
 
28 3 The Prolonged Detention Class only seeks relief under Count Two, so this class is not implicated in the 
instant cross-motions.     
-10- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 11 of 26   Page ID
   #:2562
to raise triable issues of fact and defeat summary judgment.  Thornhill Publ’g Co. v. GTE 
1
Corp., 594 F.2d 730, 738 (9th Cir. 1979).  The material the parties present must be the 
2
type that would be admissible in evidence.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c).

A.  Petitioners’ First Proposed Declaration

4
  Petitioners’ first proposed declaration states that “[t]here is generally no significant

i.  Whether pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants are significantly likely

12
 
13
  Before pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants can be removed to Vietnam, ICE must 
14

16

18

23

24
Vietnam issued 5 travel documents (9.3 percent).  (Id. ¶ 3.)  In total, between 2017 and 
25
2019, ICE requested travel documents for pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants 251 times.  
26
Vietnam granted those requests only 18 times, in just over seven percent of cases.

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 14 of 26   Page ID
   #:2565
  
1
ii.  Petitioners’ proposed declaration is improper  
2
 
3
  Petitioners’ proposed declaration essentially reiterates the government’s past 
4
position and states that in general, pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants are not significantly 
5
likely to be removed.  (Mot. at 24.)  Though Petitioners’ statistics on this point are 
6
compelling, the Court cannot issue this proposed declaration.   
7
 
8
  Under the Declaratory Judgment Act, “in a case of actual controversy within its 
9
jurisdiction . . . any court of the United States . . . may declare the rights and other legal 
10
relations of any interested party seeking such declaration.”  28 U.S.C. § 2201(a).  It is 
11
well established that “federal courts retain substantial discretion in deciding whether to 
12
grant declaratory relief.”  Ernst & Young v. Depositors Econ. Prot. Corp., 45 F.3d 530, 
13
534 (1st Cir. 1995); see Hewitt v. Helms, 482 U.S. 755, 762 (1987).  Declaratory relief is 
14
appropriate “(1) when the judgment will serve a useful purpose in clarifying and settling 
15
the legal relations in issue, and (2) when it will terminate and afford relief from the 
16
uncertainty, insecurity, and controversy giving rise to the proceeding.”  Bilbrey by 
17
Bilbrey v. Brown, 738 F.2d 1462, 1470 (9th Cir. 1984).  However, “federal courts may 
18
not give opinions upon moot questions or abstract propositions.”  Calderon v. Moore, 518 
19
U.S. 149, 150 (1996) (internal quotation omitted). 
20
 
21
  “The duty of this court . . . is to decide actual controversies by a judgment which 
22
can be carried into effect.”  Mills v. Green, 159 U.S. 651, 653 (1895).  Thus, the Court 
23
cannot issue a declaration that would be devoid of practical effect.  See Calderon, 518 
24
U.S. at 150; In re Iraq and Afghanistan Detainees Litig., 479 F. Supp. 2d 85, 118 (D.D.C. 
25
2007) (“[A] declaratory judgment should be declined when it would serve only as a 
26
statement [] without any practical enforcement effect.”).  Petitioners have not explained 
27
what practical effect, if any, their proposed declaration would have.  Nor could they do so 
28
-14- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 15 of 26   Page ID
   #:2566
persuasively.  If this Court issued the proposed declaration, individual pre-1995 
1
Vietnamese immigrants would still be required to establish that they specifically are not 
2
significantly likely to be removed in order to secure release from detention.  A statement 
3
from this Court that “in general,” pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants are unlikely to be 
4
removed would be of little use to them.  Such an abstract pronouncement would not have 
5
any bearing on clarifying the rights of the parties, nor would it resolve any legal claim.  
6
See S. Jackson & Son, Inc. v. Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exch. Inc., 24 F.3d 427, 431 (2d 
7
Cir. 1994) (affirming the lower court’s declination to issue declaratory relief because the 
8
proposed declaration did “not carry any implications for practical enforcement upon the 
9
parties” and would be “a declaration . . .  and nothing more”).  Rather, the proposed 
10
declaration would function only as an advisory opinion, which no federal court is 
11
empowered to issue.  See Desert Water Agency v. U.S. Dep’t of the Int., 849 F.3d 1250, 
12
1258 (9th Cir. 2017) (“The declaratory judgment procedure . . . may not be made the 
13
medium for securing an advisory opinion in a controversy which has not arisen.”) 
14
(internal quotations omitted).  Accordingly, Petitioner’s motion for summary judgment is 
15
DENIED as to the first proposed declaration.

B.  Petitioners’ Second Proposed Declaration  
18
 
19
  The second proposed declaration concerns the burden-shifting framework 
20
established by the Supreme Court in Zadvydas v. Davis, 533 U.S. 678 (2001).  It pertains 
21
to the 180-Day Class, which is comprised of “all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who 
22
have been or will be detained by ICE for more than 180 days after receiving removal 
23
orders.”  (Class Cert. Order at 2.)  Under Zadvydas, aliens seeking release from custody 
24
bear the initial burden of providing “good reason to believe that there is no significant 
25
likelihood of removal in the reasonably foreseeable future.”  See 533 U.S. at 701.  Once 
26
that initial showing is made, the burden shifts to the Government to respond with 
27
evidence sufficient to rebut it.  Id.  Petitioners’ proposed declaration would allow every 
28

180-Day Class member to bypass the first step of the Zadvydas framework in future cases 
1
by declaring that, as a class, there is “good reason to believe” that their removal is not 
2
significantly likely.  (Mot. at 24.) 
3
 
4
  Respondents contend that this proposed declaration cannot be issued on a class-
5
wide basis.  They argue that, inevitably, some class members are, in fact, likely to be 
6
removed because Vietnam issues travels documents in a small, but non-negligible portion 
7
of cases.  In these instances, the class members in question will be unable to meet their 
8
initial burden of showing there is “good reason to believe” that they are not significantly 
9
likely to be removed.  See Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 701.  Essentially, the government argues 
10
that because some class members will not be able to show that there is “good reason to 
11
believe” that their removal is not significantly likely, issuing a class-wide declaration 
12
would be improper.  The Court agrees.     
13
 
14
  The 180-Day Class was certified under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2).  
15
(Class Cert. Order.)  Rule 23(b)(2) classes are entitled to injunctive or declaratory relief 
16
only if “a single injunction or declaratory judgment would provide relief to each member 
17
of the class.”  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 360 (2011).  “The key to the 
18
(b)(2) class is the indivisible nature of the injunctive or declaratory remedy warranted—
19
the notion that the [defendant’s] conduct is such that it can be enjoined or declared 
20
unlawful only as to all of the class members or as to none of them.”  Id. (internal 
21
quotations omitted).  Thus, Rule 23(b)(2) classes cannot obtain class-wide relief when 
22
“each individual class member would be entitled to a different injunction or declaratory 
23
judgment against the defendant.”  Id.  In light of these principles, Rule 23(b)(2) remedies 
24
are “generally inappropriate in actions raising significant individual liability or defense 
25
issues.”  Ramirez v. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, 338 F. Supp. 3d 1, 47 
26
(D.D.C. 2018) (internal quotation omitted).   
27
 
28
-16- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 17 of 26   Page ID
   #:2568
  Petitioners’ proposed declaration clashes with the rule that relief under Rule 
1
23(b)(2) must be appropriate for “each member of the class.”  Wal-Mart Stores, 564 U.S. 
2
at 360.  When the Court certified the 180-Day Class in 2018, it did so based on  the 
3
understanding that ICE maintained a policy of detaining pre-1995 Vietnamese 
4
immigrants beyond the initial removal period despite Vietnam’s uniform policy of 
5
refusing to issue travel documents for them.  (Class Cert. Order at 15; FAC ¶ 66 [alleging 
6
that class members were being detained despite being “specifically excluded from 
7
repatriation under the repatriation agreement”].)  This presumed uniformity is what made 
8
potential class-wide declaratory relief under Rule 23(b)(2) appropriate.  It has since 
9
become clear that these uniform policies and practices are no longer in effect.  The parties 
10
now agree that Vietnam does not maintain a blanket policy of refusing to repatriate pre-
11
1995 immigrants.  (Resp. Statement ¶ 8.)  Instead, Vietnam now considers each request 
12
from ICE on a case-by-case basis.  (Id.)  ICE frequently requests travel documents from 
13
Vietnam for pre-1995 immigrants, and Vietnam issues them in a non-negligible portion 
14
of cases.  (Resp. Statement ¶¶ 9–12; Dkt. 115)   
15
 
16
  Petitioners do not appear to dispute that once Vietnam issues a travel document, 
17
removal becomes significantly likely, rendering class members unable to meet their 
18
initial burden under Zadvydas.  See Alfaro-Mejia v. Holder, 2013 WL 599876, at *1 
19
(C.D. Cal. Feb. 15, 2013) (holding that petitioner could not demonstrate that there is no 
20
significant likelihood of her removal in the reasonably foreseeable future because “travel 
21
documents for petitioner’s return to El Salvador have been issued recently”); Kumar v. 
22
Gonzales, 555 F. Supp. 2d 1061, 1065 (N.D. Cal. 2008) (same).  Nor do they dispute that 
23
in some instances, Vietnam has issued travel documents for pre-1995 immigrants.  (Resp. 
24
Statement ¶¶ 9–12; Mot. at 16.)  Accordingly, a class-wide declaration stating that each 
25
180-Day Class member has met his or her initial burden under Zadvydas would run 
26
counter to the facts in cases where Vietnam responds to ICE requests with travel 
27
documents.  Because not all class members would be entitled to the proposed relief, the 
28
-17- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 18 of 26   Page ID
   #:2569
proposed declaration is improper under Rule 23(b)(2).  See Wal-Mart Stores, 564 U.S. at 
1
360; Jennings v. Rodriguez, 138 S. Ct. 830, 852 (2018) (suggesting that Rule 23(b)(2) 
2
was an improper vehicle when “some members of the certified class may not be entitled 
3
to [the requested relief]”). 
4
 
5
  Furthermore, Rule 23(b)(2) remedies are inappropriate in situations where “highly 
6
individualized determinations of liability and remedy are made.”  Jamie S. v. Milwaukee 
7
Pub. Schools, 668 F.3d 481, 499 (7th Cir. 2012).5  Such determinations are required to 
8
resolve individual Zadvydas claims.  Typically, class members bring Zadvydas claims in 
9
individual habeas proceedings in federal courts across the county.  (See Dkt. 73-1 [listing 
10
71 individual habeas proceedings filed by pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants in 2017 and 
11
2018].)  Once a challenge is made, the presiding court typically engages in a fact-
12
dependent inquiry regarding whether the petitioner has shown there is “good reason to 
13
believe” that he or she is not significantly likely to be removed, and, if that is the case, 
14
whether the government has rebutted the showing.  See, e.g., Jaime F. v. Barr, 2020 WL 
15
2316437, at *5 (D.N.J. May 11, 2020).  These determinations often hinge on specific 
16
evidence concerning the government’s progress (or lack thereof) in obtaining travel 
17
documents for specific the petitioner.  See, e.g., Azad v. Immigration & Customs 
18
Enforcement, 2009 WL 2569132, at *2 (S.D.N.Y. Aug. 19, 2009) (finding that ICE failed 
19
to rebut a showing by petitioner by analyzing specific contacts that ICE had with the 
20
local Consulate of Bangladesh); Mohamed v. Ashcroft, 2002 WL 32620339, at *1 (W.D. 
21
Wash. Apr. 15, 2002) (granting relief where government failed to offer any “specific 
22
information regarding how or when [it] expect[ed] to obtain the necessary documentation 
23
24
 
25 5 Compare Nightingale v. U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Servs, 333 F.R.D. 449, 463 (N.D. Cal. 
2019) (finding that class-wide relief under Rule 23(b)(2) was appropriate because the plaintiff did “not 
26
seek relief with respect to the determinations made on individual A-File FOIA requests” but “rather 
challenge Defendants’ pattern or practice of refusing to timely make such determinations”) with C.G.B. 
27
v. Wolf, 2020 WL 2935111, at *19 (D.D.C. June 2, 2020) (denying relief under Rule 23(b)(2) when 
28 individual class-members’ cases “raise[d] thorny, individualized questions” such that the court could not 
issue “an indivisible injunction benefiting all its members at once”).   
-18- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 19 of 26   Page ID
   #:2570
or cooperation from the Ethiopian government”).  Oftentimes, Zadvydas claims require 
1
evidentiary hearings on the likelihood of removal.  See, e.g., Owino v. Napolitano, 575 
2
F.3d 952, 956 (9th Cir. 2009) (ordering the district court to hold an evidentiary hearing 
3
on the issue of whether the petitioner was significantly likely to be removed to Kenya).  
4
Clearly, each separate Zadvydas challenge requires the presiding court to consider the 
5
facts and circumstances of the individual claim.  Issuing Petitioners’ proposed declaration 
6
would preempt that individualized analysis and replace it with a one-size-fits-all 
7
approach ill-suited for the inquiry at hand.   
8
 
9
  When establishing the framework that would govern future claims brought under 
10
Zadvydas, the Supreme Court recognized that individual cases would require the lower 
11
courts to make “difficult judgments” about whether a particular alien is significantly 
12
likely to be removed.  See 533 U.S. at 700–01.  The Supreme Court has also cautioned 
13
against issuing Rule 23(b)(2) remedies in analogous situations that involve fact-
14
dependent determinations.  See Jennings, 138 S. Ct. at 852 (suggesting that Rule 23(b)(2) 
15
was improper because the individual due process claims at issue are “flexible . .  and 
16
call[] for such procedural protections as the particular situation demands”).  In light of the 
17
individualized inquiries involved in each class members’ Zadvydas claim, the Court 
18
cannot issue a sweeping declaration stating that every 180-Day Class member has 
19
established “good reason to believe” that their removal is not significantly likely.  That 
20
determination must be made in the first instance by the court addressing their individual 
21
claim.   
22
 
23
  None of the cases Petitioners cite compel a contrary result.  First, the rulings 
24
Petitioners cite occurred at the certification stage, not at summary judgment.  See e.g., 
25
Rodriguez v. Hayes, 591 F.3d 1105, 1125 (9th Cir. 2010), Parsons v. Ryan, 754 F.3d 657, 
26
688 (9th Cir. 2014).  And the relief sought in those cases was markedly different from the 
27
class-wide declaration Petitioners seek here.  In each case, plaintiffs sought a declaration 
28
-19- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 20 of 26   Page ID
   #:2571
that a government policy or practice was unlawful or an injunction requiring the 
1
government to halt an unlawful policy or practice.  See, e.g., Parson, 754 F.3d at 663.  
2
Petitioners seek something altogether different: a class-wide declaration that each 
3
individual class-members has satisfied a burden in hypothetical future cases.  Petitioners 
4
have pointed to no case in which a court has issued such a declaration.   
5
 
6
  In sum, although many class members may be able to show that there is “good 
7
reason to believe” their removal is unlikely, others will not.  The Court thus cannot find 
8
that Petitioners are entitled to a declaration that each individual class-member has 
9
satisfied their initial burden under Zadvydas.  Accordingly, it cannot craft declaratory 
10
relief that would effectively “provide relief to each member of the class.”  See Wal-Mart 
11
Stores, 564 U.S. at 360.  Petitioners’ motion for summary judgment is therefore 
12
DENIED to the extent it seeks this declaration.   
13
 
14
C.  Petitioners’ Third Proposed Declaration  
15
 
16
  Petitioners’ third proposed declaration concerns the 90-Day Class, which is 
17
comprised of “all pre-1995 Vietnamese immigrants who have been or will be detained by 
18
ICE for more than 90 days after receiving a removal order.”  (Class Cert. Order at 2.)  
19
Petitioners seek a declaration that the 90-Day Class members have rebutted the six-month 
20
“presumptively” reasonable period of detention and satisfied their initial burden under 
21
Zadvydas.   
22
 
23
i.  The Zadvydas claim is ripe  
24
 
25
  The parties do not dispute that under Zadvydas, detention beyond the initial 
26
removal period is only authorized if removal is significantly likely to occur in the 
27
reasonably foreseeable future.  Rather, they dispute when challenges under Zadvydas can 
28
-20- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 21 of 26   Page ID
   #:2572
be brought.  Again, in Zadvydas, the Supreme Court, established a “presumptively 
1
reasonable period of detention” of six months “for the sake of uniform administration in 
2
the federal courts.”  533 U.S. at 700–01.  Respondents first argue that the 90-day class’s 
3
claim is unripe because Zadvydas claims are barred until detention extends beyond the 
4
presumptively reasonable six-month period.  The Court disagrees.   
5
 
6
  The central holding of Zadvydas is that section 1231(a)(6) does not permit 
7
detention beyond the initial 90-day removal period when removal is not reasonably 
8
foreseeable.  See 533 U.S. at 699–700.  At no point did the Zadvydas Court preclude a 
9
noncitizen from challenging their detention before the end of the presumptively 
10
reasonable six-month period.  See Cesar v. Achim, 542 F. Supp. 2d 897, 903 (E.D. Wis. 
11
2008) (noting that “[n]othing about this scheme supports the conclusion . . . that the 
12
presumptive legality of detention within the first six months is irrebuttable.”); Ali v. Dep’t 
13
of Homeland Sec., 2020 WL 1666074, at *4 (S.D. Tex. Apr. 2, 2020) (same); but see 
14
Akinwale v. Ashcroft, 287 F.3d 1050, 1052 (11th Cir. 2002) (holding that “in order to 
15
state a claim under Zadvydas” the alien must show “post-removal order detention in 
16
excess of six months”).  Instead, it held that detention for less than six months was 
17
presumptively reasonable but left the lower courts to determine whether detention has 
18
“exceed[ed] a period reasonably necessary to secure removal” in individual cases.  See 
19
Zadvydas, 533 U.S. at 699.  Respondents have already raised—and this Court has already 
20
rejected—the argument that Zadvydas claims are barred during the first six months of 
21
detention.  (See MTD Order at 14.)  Respondents cite no new binding authority for their 
22
position, and the Court remains unpersuaded by it.  Zadvydas established a “guide” for 
23
approaching detention challenges, not a categorical prohibition on claims challenging 
24
detention less than six months.  See 533 U.S. at 700–01.   
25
 
26
// 
27
// 
28
-21-

   #:2573
ii.  The proposed relief is nonetheless improper  
1
   
2
  Although the Court finds that 90-Day Class members are not precluded from 
3
challenging their detentions during the “presumptively reasonable” period, the Court 
4
cannot issue the class-wide declaration they seek for the same reasons discussed above.  
5
Petitioners’ proposed declaration states: “the 90-Day Class Members have rebutted the 
6
six-month ‘presumptively’ reasonable period of detention and satisfied their initial 
7
burden under Zadvydas, shifting the burden to the government to justify their continued 
8
detention.”  (Mot. at 24.)  This proposed declaration suffers from the same flaws as the 
9
declaration discussed in the prior section.  In some instances, Vietnam will issue travel 
10
documents for 90-Day Class members, rendering them unable to both rebut the 
11
presumption and meet their initial burden.  See Wal-Mart Stores, 564 U.S. at 360.  The 
12
fact-intensive question of whether individual class members are significantly likely to be 
13
removed needs to be answered in the first instance by the court presiding over the 
14
individual claim.  Petitioners’ motion for summary judgment is DENIED to the extent it 
15
seeks a declaration that each member of the 90-Day Class has rebutted the presumption 
16
and satisfied their initial burden under Zadvydas.  
17
 
18
D.  Petitioners’ Fourth and Fifth Proposed Declarations  
19
 
20
  Finally, Petitioners seek two declarations that Respondents violated the rights 
21
Petitioners Trinh and Nguyen by detaining them for months despite the fact that they 
22
were unlikely to be removed.  Though the Court is extremely troubled by what occurred 
23
in these two individual cases, it cannot issue the retrospective declaratory relief 
24
Petitioners seek.   
25
 
26
  The disturbing facts of Trinh and Nguyen’s detentions are largely undisputed.  In 
27
2016, Trinh—a father of two who runs a small business with his wife—was convicted of 
28
-22- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 23 of 26   Page ID
   #:2574
a drug-related offense.  (Trinh Decl. ¶¶ 7–8.)  When Mr. Trinh completed his state 
1
sentence, he was transferred into ICE custody.  (Id. ¶ 10.)  He was ordered removed on 
2
July 27, 2017.  (Resp. Statement ¶ 13.)  On October 17, 2017, ICE conducted a 90-day 
3
post-order custody review (“POCR”) and decided to continue Mr. Trinh’s detention 
4
because “Vietnam had not denied him a travel document.”  (Id. ¶ 15.)  On March 13, 
5
2018—approximately nine months after his initial detention—ICE conducted a second 
6
POCR and continued Mr. Trinh’s detention again “on the ground that ICE was working 
7
with Vietnam to secure a travel document.”  (Id. ¶ 16.)  On April 16, 2018, Trinh was 
8
released on an order of supervision after ICE determined that he was not significantly 
9
likely to be removed.  (Id. ¶ 17.)   
10
 
11
  It later came to light that ICE did not even submit a travel document request for 
12
Mr. Trinh until May 23, 2018—over one month after his release.  (Id. ¶ 18.)  That request 
13
was denied about one month later.  (See id.)  Thus, ICE’s explanations for his continued 
14
detention in the POCRs—that “Vietnam had not denied him a travel document” and that 
15
“ICE was working with Vietnam to secure a travel document”—were simply untrue.  To 
16
date, ICE has offered no explanation for this injustice.  As a result of ICE’s malfeasance, 
17
Mr. Trinh was unnecessarily detained for several months of his life.   
18
 
19
  Mr. Nguyen’s experience with ICE is similarly troubling.  Nguyen—who was 
20
initially ordered removed in 2012 and had been on supervised release ever since—was re-
21
detained by ICE on October 19, 2017, after ICE requested travel documents from 
22
Vietnam.  (Id. ¶ 21.)  On December 28, 2017, Vietnam declined to issue travel documents 
23
for Nguyen and requested that he be allowed to remain in the United States on 
24
humanitarian grounds.  (Id. ¶ 22.)  After receiving this response from Vietnam, ICE 
25
26
27
28
-23- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 24 of 26   Page ID
   #:2575
inexplicably did not release Nguyen from custody until March 23, 2018, nearly three 
1
months after Vietnam declined to issue travel documents.6  (Id. ¶ 24.)   
2
 
3
  Despite the serious injustices that both Trinh and Nguyen experienced at the hands 
4
of ICE, the Court cannot grant the particular form of relief they seek in this case.  
5
Typically, declaratory relief targets prospective conduct.  Declaratory judgments are used 
6
to “afford relief from the uncertainty, insecurity, and controversy giving rise to the 
7
proceeding.”  Bilbrey, 738 F.2d at 1470.  But the declaratory relief Trinh and Nguyen 
8
seek is purely retrospective.  They seek declarations stating that their rights were violated 
9
in 2017 and 2018.  In support of their argument that they are entitled to this form of 
10
relief, Trinh and Nguyen contend that a retrospective declaration is “the only means of 
11
deterring Respondents from engaging in similar violations in the future.”  (Mot. at 21.)  
12
The Court disagrees that this is proper grounds for issuing the proposed declarations. 
13
 
14
  What makes a declaratory judgment “a proper judicial resolution of a ‘case or 
15
controversy’ rather than an advisory opinion—is in the settling of some dispute which 
16
affects the behavior of the defendant towards the plaintiff.”  Hewitt v. Helms, 482 U.S. 
17
755, 761 (1987).  However, federal courts “are not in the business of pronouncing that 
18
past actions which have no demonstrable continuing effect were right or wrong.”  
19
Spencer v. Kemna, 523 U.S. 1, 18 (1998).  Thus, “in the context of an action for 
20
declaratory relief, a plaintiff must be seeking more than a retrospective opinion that he 
21
was wrongly harmed by the defendant.”  Jordan v. Sosa, 654 F.3d 1012, 1025 (10th Cir. 
22
2011) (citing Ashcroft v. Mattis, 431 U.S. 171, 172 (1977)).  Put another way, “a 
23
declaratory judgment merely adjudicating past violations of federal law—as opposed to 
24
25
26
 
6 ICE contends that it continued to detain Nguyen because it had asked Vietnam to reconsider its refusal 
27
to issue travel documents for him.  (Resp. Statement ¶ 23.)  However, there is no evidence that Vietnam 
28 has any history of acquiescing to such requests.  Nor is there any evidence that Vietnam gave ICE any 
indication that it was actively considering the reconsideration request.    
-24- 

Case 8:18-cv-00316-CJC-GJS   Document 146   Filed 06/11/20   Page 25 of 26   Page ID
   #:2576
continuing or future violations of federal law—is not an appropriate exercise of federal 
1
jurisdiction.”  See Bayer v. Neiman Marcus Grp., Inc., 861 F.3d 853, 868 (9th Cir. 2017). 
2
 
3
  Because the declaration Petitioners seek would be nothing more than a 
4
retrospective opinion that their rights were violated, the Court cannot issue it.  See 
5
Mendia v. Garcia, 165 F. Supp. 3d 861, 894 (N.D. Cal. 2016) (declining to issue a 
6
retrospective declaratory judgment that defendants violated plaintiffs rights); Green v. 
7
Branson, 108 F.3d 1296, 1300 (10th Cir. 1997) (declining to issue a retroactive 
8
declaratory judgment that “would amount to nothing more than a declaration that he was 
9
wronged, and would have no effect on the defendants’ behavior towards him”); 
10
Rodriguez v. Tilton, 2015 WL 3507126, at *2 (E.D. Cal. June 3, 2015) (holding that 
11
federal courts are “not empowered to issue retrospective declaratory relief with respect to 
12
allegedly unconstitutional conduct that has ended”); C.F.C. v. Miami-Dade County, 349 
13
F. Supp. 3d 1236, 1254 (S.D. Fla. 2018) (dismissing claim that sought only retrospective 
14
declaratory relief when the declaration sought would be “nothing more than a gratuitous 
15
comment without any force or effect”).  Accordingly, Petitioners’ motion is DENIED to 
16
the extent it seeks retrospective declaratory relief regarding Trinh and Nguyen’s 
17
detention.
